bibl.title: James, Henry. Daisy Miller: A Comedy

front.head: EDITOR'S FOREWORD
front.p: Henry James was thirty-eight when he returned to the United States in the autumn of 1881 after an absence of six years. He had gone abroad at thirty-two a "promising" novelist. He returned with a substantial literary reputation. The stay abroad had been fruitful. He had written in succession The American, The Europeans, An International Episode, Daisy Miller, Confidence, Washington Square, The Portrait of a Lady , assembled several volumes of tales, published French Poets and Novelists and his study of Hawthorne, in addition to many fugitive pieces for the magazines.

Daisy Miller , first published in the Cornhill Magazine , had been, as James wrote his mother, "a really quite extraordinary hit" and was the story to which his name remained attached, in the public mind, even long after he had done much more important work. A slender little tale, its interest centered in the personality of his heroine and the frosty expatriate appropriately named Winterbourne. The story aroused controversy: had James maligned the American girl in creating the portrait of an innocent little flirt, a fresh daisy in a European garden filled with jaded blooms? James himself said that the "whole idea of the story is the little tragedy of a light, thin, natural, unsuspecting creature being sacrificed as it were to a social rumpus that went on quite over her head and to which she stood in no measurable relation."

The story was not dramatic in the sense of the theatre; but there was a drama latent in it. We do not know whether the idea of dramatization originated with James or the management of the Madison Square Theatre. The theatre, the most modern in New York, had been rebuilt in 1879 by Steele Mackaye backed by the Mallory brothers, one a clergyman, with an interest in the stage and with adequate means to cultivate it. The manager of the theatre, for the Mallorys, was Daniel Frohman, who recalled that James, "a medium-sized man with a beard" who looked like "an ordinary business man," brought him the play. He said he rejected it because, although it was "beautifully written," it was "too literary. It had too much talk and not enough action." James, however, must have also carried on negotiations with the Mallory brothers themselves, since he speaks in his journal of the proprietors who "behaved like asses and sharpers combined," adding "this episode, by itself, would make a brilliant chapter in a realistic novel." There is an allusion to the episode in a letter from William Dean Howells to James who, in describing his own troubled relations with the Madison Square Theatre, said, "When we meet, I will tell you how those gifted brothers led me on protesting over the same path you trod to the same flowery pitfall, with another play. I really begin to admire them; they are masters of no common skill."

Whatever the details of the transaction, it is clear that the entire affair left a deep impression on James. In a letter to Charles Brookfield, the actor, he said only that "the manager and I fell out ... and I returned to England with my comedy in my pocket," and to Mrs. John L. Gardner he put it: "I had a fundamental disagreement with the manager and got it back just before sailing." But this fundamental disagreement is described in his journal some months later as inspiring "deep and unspeakable disgust"; James wrote that "what it has brought [me] to know, both in New York and in London about the manners and ideas of managers and actors and about the conditions of productions on our unhappy stage, is almost fatally disgusting and discouraging. I have learned very vividly that if one attempts to work for it one must be prepared for disgust . ..."

It is unfortunate that the details are lost to us, for they might indicate, more clearly than the later experiences, what the original set-back and rejection were which so conditioned his attitude of anger and defiance toward the theatre. Allowance must be made for the possibility, however, that the managers quite simply took an option on the play and then lost interest in it, as so often happens in the theatre; and that James, unaccustomed to the "tough" realities of "show business," reacted sharply.

His memory of the writing of the play was somewhat pleasanter, and he looked back upon this period with "a kind of religious veneration." He wrote it in Boston during the three months that followed the death of his mother in January 1882. He lived in bare, ugly rooms in Mount Vernon Street which he nevertheless found comfortable and pleasant. He would walk across the Common in the morning and take his breakfast at Parker's. Then he would return to his lodgings and write until late afternoon, after which he would walk out to Cambridge, four or five days in the week, to the Quincy Street residence of the James family, there to dine with his father and sister. In the evening, under the winter stars and past the colored lamps, he would walk back along the dark and vacant roads listening to the jingle of the horse-cars. His thoughts dwelt constantly on his mother.

When he had completed the play he read it to the Boston socialite, Mrs. John L. Gardner. With the elaborate irony which characterizes all his letters to her, Henry James wrote on June 5, 1882: "I think with extraordinary tenderness of those two pretty little evenings when I read you my play. They make a charming picture — a perfect picture — in my mind, and the memory of them appeals to all that is most raffiné in my constitution. Drop a tear — a diminutive tear (as your tears must be — small but beautifully-shaped pearls) upon the fact that my drama is not after all to be brought out in New York (at least for the present). ... It is possible it may see the light here. I am to read it to the people of the St. James's Theatre next week. Please don't speak of this ."

We know that he tried to enlist the interest of Charles Brookfield and had hopes that the Bancrofts would do the play at the Haymarket, but nothing came of this. In the autumn of the year he had the play privately printed in order to circulate it more easily among the London managers. The following spring he published it in the Atlantic Monthly — in the issues of April, May and June — and later that year it appeared in book form under the imprint of James R. Osgood, after it had been rejected by Houghton and Mifflin. James made some minor revisions in the play between its private printing and its publication.

The play rewrites the original story considerably. Eugenio, the courier of the tale, becomes the villain of the piece and the shadowy lady in Geneva, briefly alluded to in the story as the friend of Winterbourne, becomes the all-important Madame de Katkoff of the play. In the tale Daisy dies of malaria and is buried in the Protestant Cemetery of Rome. In the play we are left with the promise of an early marriage between Daisy and Winterbourne. In transferring the tale to the dramatic form its freshness is lost and a rather artificial comedy is substituted which, for all its defects, reveals its author's skill in dialogue and characterization, but as yet considerable amateurishness in the manipulation of his personages and the handling of stage business. The New York Tribune devoted two columns to the book, dismissing it as a "highly impossible comedy" and adding, "we cannot repress some surprise — and regret — that such an accomplished writer and acute critic should not have perceived the full extent of the failure which he has now put permanently on record."
front.head: A NOTE ON THE TEXTS
front.p: In assembling the plays of Henry James for publication, over a period of two decades, the editor was able to collate thirty-three texts of six of the seven hitherto unpublished plays (the seventh being Summersoft of which only one text appears to be extant). The corrections and emendations were such as occur in the progress of a modern play from the dramatist's desk, through the production office into the theatre. James was called upon to revise his plays many times; typed copies were multiplied, each with different cuts and alterations. The very abundance of the texts testifies to the consistency — as well as the persistency — of his struggle within the dramatic form.

How arrive at a text Henry James would have deemed "definitive"? One could always produce a variorum edition, but neither the dramatist, nor the plays, nor the textual problems arising from collation, warranted such a procedure. Some middle course obviously was indicated that would satisfy the demands of scholarship — that is of truth, fidelity to text and to the writer's intentions — while meeting the general purpose which publication of these plays would serve: that of demonstrating their role in Henry James's half-century of creation and of providing a basic text of each play to permit students and public alike to read them and perhaps — if the fancy of some producer might be caught in the process — provide the means for the appearance of at least some of them on the American stage. I therefore directed my editing to this end.

It seemed to me that a variorum edition of at least one of the plays was justified, so that the reader might follow the problems James encountered and sought to overcome in the creation of a play. The American was ideally suited to this purpose, since there existed the original typescript of the Southport production with James's alterations in his own hand, and the printed prompt books of the London production, two of them from James's own library, as well as other copies with corrections and stage directions inserted by him or by the actors. It was thus possible to give the mutations of James's first important effort in the theatre, including a variant fourth act.

As regards the other plays, a simple principle was applied. Henry James invariably resisted the cutting of his texts. Therefore the plays had to be published in their longest, fullest form, with all the cuts restored; in a few minor instances there were cuts followed by alterations and where these were in James's hand they were accepted as his final reading; where there were simply cuts, these were put back so long as they were consistent with the rest of the text. Where later revisions made re-inclusion of any portion impossible, it was deemed wiser to adhere to the ultimate changes. No generalizations, however, can cover the problems encountered in such a multiplicity of texts and in a number of instances arbitrary editorial discretion had to be exercised; where deemed advisable, the alternate readings have been given.

There was one exception from the general rule of the fullest possible text. This was in the case of The High Bid . Having access to the Forbes-Robertsons' typescripts of the play, I decided that it would be of interest to publish the text as actually performed on the stage in 1909, which James had approved, despite a number of alterations and cuts. This play can thus be studied in its three versions: as a one-act play never performed; as the short story Covering End and in the final form it took when it reached the stage.

While James went over most of the manuscripts of his plays, making corrections and verbal changes, or inserting new portions, he did not pay close attention in certain instances to spelling or punctuation. There are inconsistencies from play to play and inconsistencies within the plays as well. Where no changes in meaning were involved, punctuation and spelling have been made consistent within each play but have been allowed to stand inconsistent from play to play. Such inconsistencies as Newman's alternately referring to "Valentin" and "Valentine" are retained as in the text as well as James's highly personal and likewise inconsistent method of obtaining emphasis or meaning through capitalization and italicization. In some of the texts the names of the characters were abbreviated before each speech; these have been spelled out as an aid to readability.

Readers seeking bibliographical information concerning the five published plays and the two rare prompt-books of The American and Guy Domville will find these fully described in LeRoy Phillips's Bibliography of the Writings of Henry James (New York, 1930), pp. 26 – 27, 46 – 47 and 115 – 16.

div.head: ACT FIRST
div.stage: Garden and terrace of an hotel on the Lake of Geneva. The portico of the hotel to the left, with steps leading up to it. In the background a low parapet dividing the garden from the lake, and divided itself by a small gate opening upon a flight of steps which are supposed to descend to a pier. Beyond this a distant view of mountains and of the lake, with the Château de Chillon. Orange-trees in green tubs, benches, a few small tables and chairs .
(MADAME DE KATKOFF, EUGENIO.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.stage: ( Coming in as if a little startled, with a French book in a pink cover under her arm .)
sp.p: I believe he means to speak to me! He is capable of any impertinence.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.stage: ( Following slowly, handsomely dressed, with a large watchguard, and a courier's satchel over his shoulder. He takes off his hat and bows obsequiously, but with a certain mock respect .)
sp.p: Madame does me the honor to recognize me, I think.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
Certainly I recognize you. I never forget my servants, especially
( with a little laugh )
the faithful ones!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Madame's memory is perhaps slightly at fault in leading her to speak of me as a servant

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: What were you, then? A friend, possibly?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: May I not say that I was, at least on a certain occasion, an adviser?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: In the way of occasions, I remember only the one on which I turned you out of the house.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: You remember it with a little regret, I hope.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: An immense deal — that I hadn't dismissed you six months sooner!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
I comprehend the regret of Madame. It was in those six months that an incident occurred —
( He pauses .)

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: An incident?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: An incident which it is natural that Madame should not have desired to come to the knowledge of persons occupying a position, however humble, near Madame.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
He is more than impertinent — he is dangerous.
( Aloud .)
You are very audacious. You took away a great deal of money.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Madame appears to have an abundance.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Yes, I have enough.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Madame is to be congratulated! I have never ceased to take an interest in Madame. I have followed her — at a distance.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: The greater the distance, the better!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Yes, I remember that Madame was very fond of her privacy. But I intrude as little as possible. I have duties at present which give me plenty of occupation. Not so much, indeed, as when I was in the employment of Monsieur de Katkoff: that was the busiest part of my life. The Russians are very exacting — the Americans are very easy!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You are with Americans now?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Madame sees that she is willing to talk! I am travelling with a family from New York — a family of three persons.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
You have no excuse then, for detaining me; you know where
to find conversation.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
Their conversation is not so agreeable as that of Madame!
( With a slight change of tone .)
I know more about you than you perhaps suspect.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I know what you know.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Oh, I don't allude to Madame's secrets. I should never be so indiscreet! It is not a secret to-day that Madame has a charming villa on this lovely lake, about three miles from Geneva.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: No, that is not a secret.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: And that though she leads a life of elegant seclusion, suited to the mourning which she has never laid aside — though she has lightened it a little — since she became a widow, Madame does not entirely shut her doors. She receives a few privileged persons.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
What on earth is he coming to?
( Aloud .)
Do you aspire to be one of them?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I should count upon it the day I should have something particular to say to Madame. But that day may never come.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Let us hope so!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Let us hope so! Meanwhile Madame is in a position to know as well as myself that — as I said just now — the Americans are very easy.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: The Americans?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Perhaps, after all, Madame doesn't find them so? Her most privileged visitor is of that nationality! Has he discovered — like me — that the Russians are very exacting?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.stage: ( Looking at him a moment, then quickly, though with an effort .)
sp.p: The Russians, when their antagonists go too far, can be as dangerous as anyone else! I forget your nationality.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I am not sure that Madame ever knew it. I'm an Italian Swiss, a native of the beautiful city of Lugano. Is Madame acquainted with Lugano? If she should go that way, I recommend the Hôtel Washington: always our Americans, you see! The Russians? They are the most dangerous people I know, and we gentlemen who take charge of families know everything.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You had better add frankly that you traffic in your knowledge.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: What could be more just? It costs us a good deal to get it.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
It is best to know the worst, and have done with it.
( Aloud .)
How much do you want?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: How much do I want for what? For keeping quiet about Mr. Winterbourne, so that his family shan't think he's wasting his time, and come out from America to bring him home? You see I know even his name! He's supposed to be at Geneva for purposes of study.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: How much do you want to go away and never let me see you again? Be merciful. Remember that I'm not rich.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I know exactly the fortune of Madame! She is not rich, for very good reasons — she was exceedingly extravagant in her youth! On the other hand, she is by no means in misery. She is not rich, like the American lady — the amiable Mrs. Miller — whom I have at present the honor to serve; but she is able to indulge herself with the usual luxuries.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It would be a luxury to get rid of you!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Ah, I'm not sure that Madame can afford that; that would come under the head of extras! Moreover, I'm not in want of money. The amiable Mrs. Miller —

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: The amiable Mrs. Miller is as great a fool as I?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I should never think of comparing her with Madame! Madame has much more the appearance of one who is born to command. It is for this reason that I approached her with the utmost deliberation. I recognized her three days ago, the evening she arrived at the hotel, and I pointed her out to Mrs. Miller as a Russian lady of great distinction, whose husband I had formerly the honor to serve in a very confidential position. Mrs. Miller has a daughter even more amiable than herself, and this young lady was profoundly impressed with the distinguished appearance of Madame.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
Her good opinion is doubtless of great value; but I suppose it's
hardly to assure me of that —

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I may add that I didn't permit myself to make any further remarks.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: And your discretion's an example of what you are capable of doing? I should be happy to believe it, and if you have not come to claim your reward —

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
My reward? My reward shall be this: that we leave the account open between us!
( Changing his tone entirely .)
Let me speak to you very frankly. Some eight years ago, when you were thirty years old, you were living at Dresden.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I was living at Dresden, but I was not thirty years old.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: The age doesn't matter — we will call it twenty, if you like — that makes me younger, too. At that time I was under your roof; I was the confidential servant, on a very exceptional footing, of M. de Katkoff. He had a great deal of business — a great deal of diplomatic business; and as he employed me very often to write for him — do you remember my beautiful hand? — I was not so much a servant as a secretary. At any rate, I was in a position to observe that you had a quarrel with your husband.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: In a position? I should think you were! He paid you to spy upon me.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: To spy upon you?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: To watch me — to follow me — to calumniate me.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: That's just the way you used to talk! You were always violent, and that gave one an advantage.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: All this is insupportable. Please to spare me your reminiscences, and come to the point.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: The point is this — that I got the advantage of you then, and that I have never lost it! Though you didn't care for your husband, you cared for someone else; and M. de Katkoff — with my assistance, if you will — discovered the object of your preference. Need I remind you of what followed, the day this discovery became known to you? Your surprise was great, because you thought yourself safe; but your anger was even greater. You found me for a moment in your path, and you imagined — for that moment — that I was a Russian serf. The mistake had serious consequences. You called me by the vilest of names — and I have never forgotten it!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I thank you for reminding me of my contempt. It was extremely sweet.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: It made you very reckless. I got possession of two letters, addressed to the person I speak of, and singularly rash compositions. They bear your signature in full.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Can there be any better proof that I have nothing to be ashamed of?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: You were not ashamed then, because, as I have already remarked, you were reckless. But to-day you are wise.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Whatever I have said — I have always signed!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: It's a habit I appreciate. One of those letters I gave to M. de Katkoff; the other — the best — I kept for myself.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: What do you mean by the best?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I mean — the worst!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It can't be very bad.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Should you like me to submit it to a few of your friends?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
Horrible man!
( Aloud .)
That's the point, then: you wish to sell it.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: No; I only wish you to know I have it.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I knew that already. What good does it do you?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: You suspected it, but you didn't know it. The good it does me is this — that when, as sometimes happens to us poor members of a despised and laborious class, I take stock of my prospects and reckon up the little advantages I may happen to possess, I like to feel that particular one among them.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I see — you regard it as a part of your capital. But you draw no income.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Ah, the income, Madame, is accumulating!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: If you are trying to frighten me, you don't — very much!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
Very much — no! But enough is as good as a feast. There is no telling what
may happen. We couriers have our ups and downs, and some day I may be in distress. Then, and only then, if I feel a pinch, I shall call on Madame. For the present —

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: For the present, you only wish to insult me!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Madame does injustice to my manners: they are usually much appreciated. For the rest of the time that we remain under the same roof — so to speak — I shall not again disturb your meditations.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Be so good as to leave me.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
I wish Madame a very good morning!
( He goes into the hotel .)

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
That's what it is to have been a fool — for a single moment! That moment reechoes through eternity. He has shaken my nerves, and in this wretched garden one is always observed.
( Exit into the hotel .)

div.stage: (MRS. COSTELLO, MISS DURANT, CHARLES REVERDY. They come out of the hotel as MME. DE KATKOFF passes into it, looking at her attentively .)

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: That's the biggest swell in the house — a Russian princess!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: A Russian princess is nothing very great. We have found one at every hotel.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Well, this is the best of them all. You would notice her anywhere.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: The best bred people are the people you notice least.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: She's very quiet, any way. She speaks to no one.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: You mean by that that no one speaks to her.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
The old lady's snappish this morning: hanged if I'll stand it!
( Aloud .)
No one speaks to her, because no one ventures to.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: You ventured to, I think, and she didn't answer you. That's what you mean by her being quiet!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: She dropped her fan, and I picked it up and gave it to her She thanked me with a smile that was a poem in itself: she didn't need to speak!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: You needn't mind waiting on Russian princesses. Your business is to attend to us — till my nephew comes.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: As I understand you, he's already due.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: He's a quarter an hour late. We are waiting breakfast.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I'm afraid the delay will bring on one of your headaches.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I have one already, so it doesn't matter!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
Very convenient, those headaches!
( Aloud .)
Won't you sit down, at least?
( Offering camp-stool .)
You know I don't come out for three minutes without our little implement.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I don't care for that; I'll sit on a bench.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
She insists on my bringing it, and yet she won't use it!
( The ladies seat themselves, and he places himself between them, astride the camp-stool. He continues, aloud .)
If Mr. Winterbourne is already due, my holiday has legally begun.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: You won't lose anything by waiting. After he comes you will be at perfect liberty.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Oh yes, after that you won't look at me, I suppose! Miss Durant is counting very much on Mr. Winterbourne.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: And I am counting very much on Miss Durant. You are to be very nice to him, you know.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: That will depend on how I like him.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: That's not what I brought you to Europe for — to make conditions. Besides, Frederick's a perfect gentleman.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: You seem to wish me to promise to marry him. I must wait till he asks me, you know.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: He will ask you if Mrs. Costello bids him. He is evidently in excellent training.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I haven't seen him for ten years: at that time he was a model nephew.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: I shouldn't wonder if he were to turn out a regular "hard" one. That would be a jolly lark!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: That's not his reputation. Moreover, he has been brought up in Geneva, the most moral city in Europe.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: You can't tell anything from that. Here am I, brought up in New York — and we all know what New York is. Yet where can you find a more immaculate young man? I haven't a fault — I'm ashamed of myself!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: If Mr. Winterbourne is a little wild, I shan't like him any the less. Some faults are very charming.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Tell me what they are, and I'll try and acquire them.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: My dear Alice, I'm startled by your sentiments. I have tried to form your taste ...

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Yes, but you have only cultivated my dislikes. Those are a few of my preferences.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Tell us a few more of them — they sound awfully spicy!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I'm very fond of a certain indifference. I like men who are not always running after you with a camp-stool, and who don't seem to care whether you like them or not.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: If you like rude men, they are very easily found. If I didn't know you were a very nice girl, I should take you for — I don't know what!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
Miss Durant's remarks are addressed to me, and between you two ladies it's hard to know what to do. You want me to be always at your elbow, and you make a great point of the camp-stool. Will you have it a little, for a change?
( Getting up and offering it . MRS. COSTELLO refuses with a gesture .)
I don't offer it to Miss Alice; we have heard what she think of it!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I didn't speak of that piece of furniture: I spoke of the person who carries it.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: The person who carries, the camp-stool? Is that what I've come to be known by? Look here, my dear friends, you ought to engage a courier.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: To cheat us out of our eyes? Thank you very much!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: A courier with a gorgeous satchel, and a feather in his hat — like those ladies from Schenectady!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: So that he might smoke in our faces, as he does in theirs, and have his coffee with us after dinner, as he does with them? They have ruined a good servant.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: They treat him as an equal; they make him their companion.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: But they give him handsome wages — which is more than you do me!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I have no doubt they give him little tokens of affection, and locks of their hair. But that makes them only the more dreadful!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I'm glad to see, my dear, that your taste is coming back to you!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Oh, if taste consists in demolishing Miss Daisy Miller, she can take the prize.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Demolishing her? I should be sorry to take that trouble. I think her very vulgar: that's all!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Miss Daisy Miller? Is that her distinguished name?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Ah, we can't all be named Costello!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: They are the sort of Americans that one does one's duty by not accepting.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Ah, you don't accept her?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I would if I could — but I can't. One should let Europeans know —

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: One should let them know?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: That we are not all like that.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: They can see it for themselves: she's charmingly pretty.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: You are extremely impertinent.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
I put in one that time.
( Aloud .)
I can't help it; she's lovely.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: And is the mamma lovely, too? Has any one ever seen the mamma?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: She's sick in bed — she's always sick.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: The courier sits with her, and gives her her medicine.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: I hope you call that devoted, then?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: It doesn't matter, because the head of the family is the little boy. He orders the dinner; he has the best seat in the carriage.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
He's the most amusing little
specimen. He has the heart of a patriot in the body of a —
( Hesitates lor a word .)

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: In the body of a grasshopper!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: He hops a good deal, or, rather, I should say, he flies; for there is a good deal of the spread-eagle about him.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: He leaves his toys all over the hotel; I suppose you would say his plumes.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Well, he's a dauntless American infant; a child of nature and of freedom.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Oh, nature and freedom! We have heard too much of them .

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Wait till you are stopped at the New York custom-house! The youthful Miller and I have struck up a friendship: he introduced me to his sister.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: You don't mean to say you spoke to her!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Spoke to her? Yes, indeed — and she answered me.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: She was not like the Russian princess!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: No, she's as little as possible like the Russian princess; but she's very charming in another style. As soon as Mr. Winterbourne arrives (and you must excuse me for saying that he takes a deuce of a time about it), I shall console myself for the loss of your society by plunging into that of the Millers.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: You won't lose us, Mr. Reverdy: you can console yourself with me.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Oh, thank you!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Frederick will devote himself to Alice.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: We had better wait till he comes! I have no patience with his delay.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Neither have I, my dear; but I may as well take the opportunity of remarking that a young lady shouldn't seem too eager ...

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Too eager?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: For the arrival of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I see what you mean — more reserve. But simply before you ...

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: And before me, please. Am I nobody?

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Nobody at all!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Well, I don't care, for I descry in the distance the adorable Miss Miller!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I'm glad she's in the distance.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Ah, but she's coming this way.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I forbid you to speak to her.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
Ah, then I am somebody?
( Aloud .)
I can't cut the poor girl, you know.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: You needn't see her. You can look at me.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: She's always wandering about the garden — the image of idleness and inanity.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: She's not as serious as we, nor as well occupied, certainly; but she's bored to death. She has got no one to flirt with.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: She shall not flirt with you, at any rate!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Do you wish me to hide behind a tree?

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p:
No, you can sit down here
( indicating the bench beside her ),
and take my parasol — so! — and hold it before your face, as if you were shading your eyes.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
From Miss Daisy Miller? It's true she's very dazzling!
(DAISY enters from the right, strolling slowly, as if she has nothing to do, and passes across the stage in front of the others, who sit silent, watching her , REVERDY peeping for a moment from behind his parasol. "She was dressed in white muslin, with a hundred frills and flounces, and knots of pale-colored ribbon. She was bare-headed; but she balanced in her hand a large parasol, with a deep border of embroidery; and she was strikingly, admirably pretty." She looks at the others as she passes them, and goes out on the left — not into the hotel . REVERDY continues .)
Now, then, may I look out?

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: She saw you, I'm happy to say.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Oh yes, I gave her a wink!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: That's the way she roams about —

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Seeking whom she may devour!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Poor little creature! I'm the only tolerably good-looking young man in the hotel.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Mercy on us! I hope she won't get hold of Frederick!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Not if I can help it, dear Madam. I have never seen Frederick — but I mistrust Frederick.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: He's not at all in your style. He's had a foreign education. He speaks a dozen languages.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: An awful prig — I can see that.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Let us hope that, thanks to his foreign education, he will be out of danger. Such people as that can only disgust him.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: I know the style of fellow you mean — a very high collar and a very stiff spine! He speaks a dozen languages — but he doesn't speak the language of Schenectady. He won't understand an American girl — he had better leave her alone.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I am very much obliged to you — for me!

div.stage: ( Enter a WAITER from the hotel .)

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Oh, you are not an American; you're an angel!

sp.speaker: THE WAITER.
sp.p: The breakfast that Madame ordered is served.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: It's just twelve o'clock; we certainly can't wait any longer.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I don't believe he's coming at all!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Ah, if I've only brought on a headache for nothing!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
Won't he catch it when he arrives?
( They pass into the hotel, the WAITER leading the way .)

div.stage: (EUGENIO, then WINTERBOURNE and the WAITER. EUGENIO comes out of the hotel, then looks about him and begins to call. He is without his hat and satchel .)

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
Meester Randolph! Meester Randolph! Confound that infernal child — it's the fifth time this morning that I've chased him round the garden!
( Stands calling again .)
Meester Randolph! Meester Randolph! He is always there when he's not wanted and never when he is, and when I find him I haven't even the right to pinch his ear! He begins to kick like a little mule, and he has nails in his boots — for the mountains. Meester Randolph! Meester Randolph! Drat the little wretch — I'm a courier, not a nurse!
( Exit to the right, while WINTERBOURNE comes down from the hotel, followed by a WAITER, the same who has just appeared, carrying a little tray with a service of black coffee .)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
I will have my coffee here, it's so close in the hotel.
( The WAITER places the tray on a small table, which he draws up to a bench . WINTERBOURNE takes out a card, on which, on his pocket-book, he writes a few words .)
And please take that card to the lady whose name I have written there, and ask her when it will be convenient for her to see me.

sp.speaker: THE WAITER.
sp.p: The Russian lady who arrived three days ago? I will let you know, sir.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Wait a moment. Do you know whether Mrs. Costello has breakfasted?

sp.speaker: THE WAITER.
sp.p: Mrs. Costello? The lady with the young lady, and the gentleman also young?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I know nothing about her companions. A lady with her hair very high. She is rather — rather —

sp.speaker: THE WAITER.
sp.p: Yes, sir, she is rather high altogether! When she gives an order —

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I don't ask you to describe her — I ask you if she has breakfasted.

sp.speaker: THE WAITER.
sp.p: The party's at table now, sir. I conducted them myself, five minutes ago. I think they waited for you, sir; they expected you to arrive.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
I arrived an hour ago, by the train; but I was dusty, and I had to have a bath.
( Lighting a cigarette .)
Then while I dressed, to save time, I had my breakfast brought to my room. Where do they usually take their coffee?

sp.speaker: THE WAITER.
sp.p: They take it in our beautiful garden, sir.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Very good. I will wait for them here. That's all.
( The WAITER re-enters the hotel . WINTERBOURNE puffs his cigarette .)
There is no use in being in a hurry. I want to be eager — but I don't want to be too eager. That worthy man is quite right; when Aunt Louisa gives an
order, it's a military command. She has ordered me up from Geneva, and I've marched at the word; but I'll rest a little before reporting at headquarters.
( Puffs his cigarette .)
It coincides very happily, for I don't know that, without this pretext, I should have ventured to come. Three days ago, the waiter said? A week ago, at the villa, they told me she had gone. There is always a mystery in that woman's movements. Yes, Aunt Louisa is rather high; but it's not of her I'm afraid!
( Puffs a moment in silence .)

div.stage: (WINTERBOURNE, RANDOLPH, then DAISY.)

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.stage: ( He comes in from the back, approaches WINTERBOURNE, and stops. "The child, who was diminutive for his years, had an aged expression of countenance, a pale complexion, and sharp little features. He was dressed in knickerbockers, with red stockings, which displayed his poor little spindleshanks; he also wore a brilliant red cravat. He carried in his hand a long alpenstock, the sharp point of which he thrust into everything that he approached — the flower-beds, the garden-benches. ... In front of WINTERBOURNE he paused, looking at him with a pair of bright, penetrating little eyes." [Footnote: 1Kb From the story. [Henry James's footnote] WINTERBOURNE, smoking, returns his gaze .)
sp.p: Will you give me a lump of sugar?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Yes, you may take one; but I don't think sugar is good for little boys.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.stage: ( He steps forward and carefully possesses himself of the whole contents of the plate. From these he still more carefully selects the largest lump, depositing the others in his pocket. Biting, with a grimace .)
sp.p: Oh, blazes! it's hard!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Take care, young man. You'll hurt your teeth.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I haven't got any teeth to hurt; they've all come out. I've only got seven teeth. Mother counted them last night, and one came out afterwards. She said she'd slap me if any more came out. I can't help it — it's this old Europe. It's the climate that makes 'em come out. In America, they didn't come out; it's these hotels!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: If you eat all that sugar, your mother will certainly slap you.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: She's got to give me some candy, then. I can't get any candy here — any American candy. American candy's the best.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: And are American boys the best little boys?

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I don't know. I'm an American boy!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I see you are one of the best.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: That isn't what my mother says, you can bet your life on that!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, your mother's too modest!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.stage: ( Astride his alpenstock, looking at WINTERBOURNE.)
sp.p: She's sick — she's always sick. It's this old Europe! Are you an American man?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Oh, yes, a fellow-citizen.
( Aside .)
I wonder whether I was once like that!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: American men are the best.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: So they often say.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Here comes my sister. She's an American girl.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: American girls are the best girls.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Oh, my sister ain't the best. She's always blowing at me!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
I imagine that's your fault, not hers.
(DAISY comes in from the left in the same manner as on her previous entrance, and on reaching the middle of the stage stops and looks at WINTERBOURNE and at RANDOLPH, who has converted his alpenstock into a vaulting-pole, and is springing about violently . WINTERBOURNE continues, getting up .)
By Jove, how pretty!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, Randolph, what are you doing?

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I'm going up the Alps. This is the way!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: That's the way they come down.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: He's all right; he's an American man!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
It seems to me
that I have been in a manner presented.
( Approaches DAISY, throwing away his cigarette. Aloud, with great civility .)
This little boy and I have made acquaintance.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.stage: ( She looks at him a moment serenely, and then, as if she had scarcely heard him, addresses RANDOLPH again .)
sp.p: I should like to know where you got that pole!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: The same way as you get your things. I made Eugenio buy it.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: With a little commission!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You don't mean to say you're going to take that pole to Italy?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Are you thinking of going to Italy?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.stage: ( Looking at him, and then looking away .)
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Are you going over the Simplon?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I don't know — I suppose it's some mountain. Randolph, what mountain are we going over?

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Going where?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
To Italy.
( Arranging her ribbons .)
Don't you know about Italy?

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: No, and I don't want to. I want to go to America!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, Italy's a beautiful place.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Can you get any candy there?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I hope not! I guess you have had candy enough, and mother thinks so too.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I haven't had any for ever so long — for a hundred weeks!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
Why, Randolph, I don't see how you can tell —
( She pauses a moment .)
Well I don't care!
( Looks down at her dress, and continues to smooth her ribbons .)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Does she accept my acquaintance or not? It's rather sudden, and it wouldn't do at Geneva. But why else did she come and plant herself in front of me? She is the prettiest of the pretty, and, I declare, I'll risk it!
( After a moment, aloud .)
We are very fortunate in our weather, are we not?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, yes, we've got nice weather.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
And still more fortunate in our scenery.
( Indicating the view .)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, yes, the scenery's lovely. It seems very mountainous.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah, Switzerland is mountainous, you know.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I don't know much about it. We have only been here a week.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: In a week one can see a good deal.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, we haven't; we have only walked round a little.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
What a remarkable type!
( Aloud .)
You must be rather tired: there are plenty of chairs.
( Draws forward two of them .)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You'll be very clever if you can get Randolph to sit.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
I don't care a fig about Randolph.
(DAISY seats herself. Aside .)
Oh, Geneva, Geneva!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, he's only nine. We've sat round a good deal, too.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It's very pleasant, these summer days.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, yes, it's very pleasant. But it's nicer in the evening.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Ah, much nicer in the evening. It's remarkably nice in the evening.
( Aside .)
What the deuce is she coming to?
( Aloud .)
When you get to Italy you'll find the evenings there! ...

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I've heard a good deal about the evenings there.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: In Venice, you know — on the water — with music!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
I don't know much about it.
( With a little laugh .)
I don't know much about anything!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Heaven forgive her, she's charming! I must really ascertain ...
( To RANDOLPH, who has continued to roam about, and who comes back to them with his alpenstock, catching him and drawing him between his knees .)
Tell me your name, my beautiful boy!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Well, you drop me first!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Why, Randolph, I should think you'd like it!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Jupiter, that is a little strong!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Try it yourself! My name is Randolph C. Miller.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Alarming child! But she doesn't seem to be alarmed.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.stage: ( Levelling his alpenstock at DAISY, who averts it with her hand .)
sp.p: And I'll tell you her name.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You had better wait till you are asked.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I should like very much to know your name.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Her name is Daisy Miller.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: How very interesting!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, he's a queer specimen! I guess he's laughing.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: That isn't her real name — that isn't her name on her cards.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: It's a pity that you haven't got one of my cards!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Her name is Annie P. Miller.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Oh, I see.
( Aside .)
That doesn't tell me much.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Ask him his name.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Ask him yourself! My father's name is Ezra B. Miller. My father ain't in Europe. My father's in a better place than Europe.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah, you have had the misfortune ...

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: My father's in Schenectady. He does a big business. He's rich, you can bet your head!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, in Schenectady? I thought he meant in Paradise!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, you needn't stick your pole into my eye!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p:
Didn't I tell you she was always blowing?
( Scampers away and disappears .)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: He doesn't like Europe; he wants to go back. He hasn't got any boys here. There's one boy here, but he's always going round with a teacher.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: And your brother hasn't any teacher?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Mother thought of getting him one, to travel round with us. But Randolph said he didn't want a teacher when school didn't keep; he said he wouldn't have lessons when he was in the cars. And we are in the cars most of the time. There was an English lady we met in the cars; her name was Miss Featherstone — perhaps you know her. She wanted to know why I didn't give Randolph lessons — give him instruction, she called it. I guess he could give me more instruction than I could give him! He's very smart — he's only nine.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: He might be ninety!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Mother's going to get a teacher for him as soon as we get to Italy. Can you get good teachers in Italy?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, it's the land of art — of science.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
Well, I guess he doesn't want to study art; but she's going to find some school, if she can.
( Pensively .)
Randolph ought to learn some more.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It depends upon what it is!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.stage: ( After a silence, during which her eyes have rested upon him .)
sp.p: I presume you are a German.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh dear, no! I shouldn't have ventured to speak to you, if your brother's mention of my nationality had not seemed a guarantee ...

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I didn't suppose my brother knew. And you do speak queerly, any way!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I'm a countryman of your own. But I should tell you that I have spent many years in this old Europe, as your brother says.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Do you live here — in the mountains?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Does she think I'm a goatherd?
( Aloud .)
No, I live just now at Geneva.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, you are peculiar, anyhow!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
So are you, if you come to that.
( Aloud .)
I'm afraid I have got rather out of the way —
( Pauses for a moment .)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Out of the way of what?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Of making myself agreeable to the young ladies.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Haven't they got any over here? I must say I haven't seen any! Of course I haven't looked out much for them.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You have looked out more for the gentlemen!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, at Schenectady I didn't have to look out.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Queer place, Schenectady.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
I had so much society. But over here —
( She hesitates .)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Over here?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, you're the first gentleman that has been at all attentive.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah, you see, they're afraid!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: And the first I've cared anything about!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
And to think that, at the beginning, I was afraid.
( Aloud .)
If they knew how kind you are they would be much less timid.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I hate gentlemen to be timid. That's only for us.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: "For us" is enchanting!

div.stage: (DAISY, WINTERBOURNE, EUGENIO, who comes in hastily from the right, wiping his forehead .)

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Mademoiselle, I have been looking for an hour for Meester Randolph. He must be drowned in the lake!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
I guess he's talking to that waiter.
( Serenely .)
He likes to talk to that waiter.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: He shouldn't talk to waiters, Mademoiselle.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Only to couriers — the hierarchy!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
I want to introduce you to a friend of mine — Mr. — Mr. —
( To WINTERBOURNE.)
I declare, I don't know your name.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: To the courier? Excuse me!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I have the honor of knowing the name of Monsieur.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Gracious, you know everything!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
The lover of the Katkoff!
( Aloud .)
I found Meester Randolph, but he escaped again.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, Eugenio, you're a splendid courier, but you can't make much impression on Randolph.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
I do what I can, Mademoiselle. The lunch is waiting, and Madame is at the table. If you will excuse me, I will give up the chase.
( Glancing at WINTERBOURNE, aside .)
Is he leaving the Katkoff for the child?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
You needn't be so grand, need he?
( To WINTERBOURNE.)
It's not the first time you've been introduced to a courier!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: The very first.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
He has never kept one.
( Aloud .)
If Mademoiselle will pass into the hotel!
( Aside again .)
The child is not for every one.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Tell mother to begin — that I'm talking to a gentleman.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I shall be very sorry to incommode your mother.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
I like the way you say such things.
( Familiarly .)
What are you going to do all day?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I hardly know. I've only just arrived.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I will come out after lunch.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I shall be here, to take your commands.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, you do say them! About two o'clock.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I shall not go far.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: And I shall learn your name from Eugenio.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
And something else as well! He is not for the child.
( Follows DAISY into the hotel .)

div.stage: (WINTERBOURNE alone, then MADAME DE KATKOFF.)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
She's simply amazing! I have never seen them like that. I have seen them worse — oh, yes! — and I have seen them better; but I've never encountered that particular shade — that familiarity, that facility, that fragility! She's too audacious to be innocent, and too candid to be — the other thing. But her candor itself is a queer affair. Coming up to me and proposing acquaintance, and letting her eyes rest on mine! Planting herself there like a flower to be gathered! Introducing me to her courier, and offering me a rendezvous at the end of twenty minutes! Are they all like that, the little American girls? It's time I should go back and see.
( Seeing MME. DE KATKOFF.)
But I can hardly go while I have this reason for staying!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.stage: ( She comes out of the hotel; she has still her book under her arm .)
sp.p: They brought me your card, but I thought it better I should come and see you here.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I know why you do that: you think it's less encouraging than to receive me in-doors.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Oh, if I could discourage you a little!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It's not for want of trying. I bore you so much!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: No, you don't bore me, but you distress me. I give you so little.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: That's for me to measure. I'm content for the present.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: If you had been content, you wouldn't have followed me to this place.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I didn't follow you, and, to speak perfectly frankly, it's not for you I came.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Is it for that young lady I just saw from my window?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I never heard of that young lady before. I came for an aunt of mine, who is staying here.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Ah, if your family could only take an interest in you!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Don't count on them too much. I haven't seen my aunt yet.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You have asked first for me? You see, then, it was for me you came.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I wish I could believe it pleased you a little to think so.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It does please me — a little; I like you very much.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You always say that, when you are about to make some particularly disagreeable request. You like me, but you dislike my society. On that principle, I wish you hated me!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I may come to it yet.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Before that, then, won't you sit down?
( Indicating a bench .)

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Thank you; I'm not tired.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: That would be too encouraging! I went to the villa a week ago. You had already left it.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I went first to Lausanne. If I had remained there, you wouldn't have found me.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I'm delighted you didn't remain. But I'm sorry you are altering your house.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Only two rooms. That's why I came away: the workmen made too much noise.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I hope they are not the rooms I know — in which the happiest hours of my life have been passed!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I see why you wished me to sit down. You want to begin a siege.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: No, I was only going to say that I shall always see with particular vividness your little blue parlor.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
They are going to change it to red.
( Aside .)
Perhaps that will cure him!
( Aloud .)
Apropos of your family, have they come to Europe to bring you home?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: As I tell you, I haven't yet ascertained their intentions.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I take a great interest in them. I feel a little responsible for you.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You don't care a straw for me!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Let me give you a proof. I think it would conduce to your happiness to return for a while to America.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: To my happiness? You are confounding it with your own.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It is true that the two things are rather distinct. But you have been in Europe for years — for years and years.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, I have been here too long. I know that.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You ought to go over and make the acquaintance of your compatriots.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Going over isn't necessary. I can do it here.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You ought at least to see their institutions — their scenery.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Don't talk about scenery, on the Lake of Geneva! As for American institutions, I can see them in their fruits.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: In their fruits?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Little nectarines and plums. A very pretty bloom, but decidedly crude. What book are you reading?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I don't know what. The last French novel.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Are you going to remain in the garden?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I see what you are coming to: you wish to offer to read to me.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: As I did in the little blue parlor!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You read very well; but we are not there now.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: A quiet corner, under the trees, will do as well.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: We neither of us have the time. I recommend you to your aunt. She will be sure to take you in hand.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I have an idea I shan't fall in love with my aunt.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I am sorry for her. I should like you as a nephew.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I should like you as a serious woman!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I am intensely serious. Perhaps you will believe it when I tell you that I leave this place to-day.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I don't call that serious: I call it cruel.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: At all events, it's deliberate. Vevey is too hot; I shall go higher up into the mountains.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You knew it was hot when you came.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Yes, but it's hotter than I supposed.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You don't like meeting old friends.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
No, nor old enemies!
( Aloud .)
I like old friends in the autumn — the melancholy season! I shall count on seeing you then.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: And not before, of course. Say at once you wish to cut me.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Very good: I wish to cut you!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You give a charm even to that! Where shall you be in the autumn?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I shall be at the villa — if the little blue parlor is altered! In the winter I shall go to Rome.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: A happy journey, then! I shall go to America.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: That's capital. Let me give you a word of advice.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Yes, that's the finishing touch!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: The little nectarines and plums: don't mind if they are a trifle crude! Pick out a fair one, a sweet one —

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Don't, don't! I shall see you before you go.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
Not if I can help it!
( Aloud .)
I think this must be your family.
( Goes into the hotel .)

div.stage: (WINTERBOURNE, MRS. COSTELLO, MISS DURANT, REVERDY, who come out of the hotel, as MME. DE KATKOFF enters it .)

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: We are always meeting the Russian princess!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: If you call that meeting her, when she never looks at you!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: She doesn't look at you, but she sees you. Bless my soul, if here isn't Frederick!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: My dear aunt, I was only waiting till you had breakfasted.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: He was talking with the Russian princess!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: You might have sat down with us: we waited an hour.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I breakfasted in my room. I was obliged on my arrival to jump into a bath.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: He's very cold — he's very cold!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: They told me you were at table, and I just sat down here.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: You were in no hurry to embrace me — after ten years?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It was just because of those ten years; they seemed to make you so venerable that I was pausing — as at the entrance of a shrine! Besides, I knew you had charming company.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: You shall discover how charming. This is Alice Durant, who is almost our cousin.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Almost? I wish it were quite.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: And that is Mr. Charles Reverdy.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Who is almost their courier!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I must relieve you of your duties.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
Oh, thank you, thank you! By George, if I'm relieved I'll look out for Miss Miller.
( Looks about him, and finally steals away .)

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: My dear Frederick, in all this time you have not changed for the worse.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: How can you tell that — in three minutes?

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Decidedly good-looking, but fearfully distant!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Oh, if you are not agreeable, we shall be particularly disappointed. We count on you immensely.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I shall do my best, dear aunt.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Especially for our sweet Alice.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Oh, Cousin Louisa, how can you?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I thought of you when I invited her to come to Europe.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It was a very happy thought. I don't mean thinking of me, but inviting Miss Durant.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I can't say it was of you I thought when I accepted.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I should never flatter myself: there are too many other objects of interest.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: That's precisely what we have been talking of. We are surrounded by objects of interest, and we depend upon you to be our guide.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: My dear aunt, I'm afraid I don't know much about them.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: You'll have a motive to-day for learning. I have an idea that you have always wanted a motive. In that stupid old Geneva there can't be many.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah, if there's one, it's enough!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: If there's one? He's in love with some dreadful Genevese!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: My young companion has a great desire to ascend a mountain — to examine a glacier.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Cousin Louisa, you make me out too bold!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
She's not bold, then, this one, like the other? I think I prefer the other.
( Aloud .)
You should go to Zermatt. You're in the midst of the glaciers there.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: We shall be delighted to go — under your escort. Mr. Reverdy will look after me!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: When he has done with Miss Daisy Miller!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Even among the glaciers, I flatter myself I can take care of both of you.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: It will be all the easier, as I never leave your aunt.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: She doesn't rush about the world alone, like so many American girls. She has been brought up like the young ladies in Geneva. Her education was surrounded with every precaution.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: With too many, perhaps! The best education is seeing the world a little.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: That's precisely what I wish her to do. When we have finished Zermatt, we wish to come back to Interlaken, and from Interlaken you shall take us to Lucerne.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Perhaps you'll draw up a little list.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p:
Perfectly polite, but no enthusiasm!
( Aloud .)
I'm afraid Mr. Winterbourne isn't at liberty; he has other friends.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: He hasn't another aunt, I imagine!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Fortunately not!
( Aloud to MISS DURANT.)
It's very charming of you to think of that.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Possibly we are indiscreet, as we just saw you talking to a lady.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Madame de Katkoff? She leaves this place to-day.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p:
You don't mean to follow her, I hope?
( Aside .)
It's best to be firm with him at the start.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: My dear aunt, I don't follow every woman I speak to.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Ah, that's meant for us! Mr. Reverdy is never so rude. I would thank him to come back.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: On the 1st of October, you know, you shall take us to Italy.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah! every one is going to Italy.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p:
Every one? Madame de
Katkoff, perhaps.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Madame de Katkoff, precisely; and Mr. Randolph C. Miller and his sister Daisy.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Bless my soul! What do you know about that?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I know what they have told me.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Mercy on us! What opportunity? —

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Just now, while I had my coffee.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: As I say, Mr. Winterbourne has a great many friends.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: He only asks to add you to the number.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Side by side with Miss Daisy Miller? Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Come, my dear Frederick, that girl is not your friend.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Upon my word, I don't know what she is, and I should be very glad if you could tell me.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: That's very easily done: she's a little American flirt.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah! she's a little American flirt!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: She's a vulgar little chatterbox.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah! she's a vulgar little chatterbox!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: She's in no sort of society.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah! she's in no sort of society!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: You would never know her in America.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: If I should never know her in America, it seems to me a reason for seizing the opportunity here.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: The opportunity appears to have come to you very easily.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I confess it did, rather. We fell into conversation while I sat there on the bench.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Perhaps she sat down beside you?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I won't deny that she did; she is wonderfully charming.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Oh! if that's all that's necessary to be charming —

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: You must give up the attempt — mustn't you, my dear? My poor Frederick, this is very dreadful!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: So it seems; but I don't understand.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: What should you say at Geneva of a young woman who made such advances?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Such advances? I don't know that they were advances.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Ah! if you wish to wait till she invites you to her room!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I shall not have to wait very long.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Hadn't I better leave you?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Poor child, I understand that you shrink ... But we must make it clear.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Oh, yes, we must make it clear!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Do make it clear; I want it to be clear.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Ask yourself, then, what they would say at Geneva.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: They would say she was rather far gone. But we are not at Geneva.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: We are only a few miles off. Miss Daisy Miller is very far gone indeed.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah! what a pity! But I thought, now, in New York —

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Frederick, don't lift your hand against your mother-country!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Never in the world. I only repeat what I hear — that over there all this sort of thing — the manners of young persons, the standard of propriety — is quite different.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I only know how I was brought up!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah, that settles it.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: We must take him back with us, to see.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Not to see, you mean — not to see my dear little friend!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: In the best society — never.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, hang the best society, then!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I am exceedingly obliged to you.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Oh, you are the best society! And the little girl with the naughty
brother is the worst?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: The worst I have ever seen.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.stage: ( Rather gravely, laying his hand on her arm .)
sp.p: My dear aunt, the best, then, ought to be awfully good!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p:
He means that for an epigram! I'll make him go and look for Mr. Reverdy.
( Aloud .)
I wonder what has become of Mr. Reverdy.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p:
Never mind Mr. Reverdy; I'll look after him.
( To WINTERBOURNE.)
If you should see a little more of those vulgar people, you would find that they don't stand the test.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Oh, I shall see a little more of them — in a quarter of an hour.
( Looking at his watch .)
The young lady is coming back at two o'clock.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Gracious goodness! Have you made an appointment?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I don't know whether it's an appointment, but she said she would come back again.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: My precious darling, we must go in. We can hardly be expected to assist at such a scene.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: My dear aunt, there is plenty of time yet.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Ah, no; she'll be before! Would you kindly look for Mr. Reverdy?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: With the greatest of pleasure.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Later in the afternoon, if this extraordinary interview is over, we should like you to go with us into the town.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
With the greatest of pleasure.
( Aside .)
They hate her ferociously, and it makes me feel sorry for her.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Quickly, my dear! We must get out of the way.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Let me at least see you into the house.
( Accompanies them into the hotel .)

div.stage: (CHARLES REVERDY, RANDOLPH, then DAISY.)

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.stage: ( Coming in from behind with the child on his back .)
sp.p: The horrid little wretch! I'm like Sinbad the Sailor with the Old Man of the Sea! Don't you think you've had about enough?

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Oh, no; I haven't had enough. I'll tell you when I've had enough.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
Oh, come! I've galloped twenty miles; I've been through all my paces. You must sit still in the saddle a while.
( Pauses in front while RANDOLPH bounces up and down .)
I'm playing horse with the brother to be agreeable to the sister; but he's riding me to death!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I want you to prance about and to kick. Get up, sir; get up!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
It's the devil's own game — here at the door of the hotel!
( Aloud .)
I'll prance about so that you'll come off.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: If you throw me off, I'll give you a licking! Get up, sir, get up!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Damn the little demon! It was a happy thought of mine.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: These are my spurs. I'll drive in my spurs! Get up, sir, get up!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
Oh misery, here goes!
( He begins to imitate the curvetting of a horse, in the hope of throwing RANDOLPH off, but, seeing DAISY issue from the hotel, suddenly stops .)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, Randolph, what are you doing up there?

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I'm riding on a mule!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: A mule? Not even the nobler animal! My dear young lady, couldn't you persuade him to dismount?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You look so funny when you say that! I'm sure I never persuaded Randolph.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: He said if I would tell him where you were, he would give me a ride.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: And then, when he was up, he refused to tell me!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I told you mother wouldn't like it. She wants Daisy and me to be proper.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: "Me to be proper"! He's really sublime, the little fiend!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, she does want you to be proper. She's waiting for you at lunch.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I don't want any lunch: there's nothing fit to eat.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, I guess there is, if you'll go and see.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: It's uncommonly nice for me, while they argue the question!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: There's a man with candy in the hall; that's where mother wants you to be proper.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: A man with candy. Oh, blazes!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Adorable creature! She has broken the spell.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I say, old mule, you can go to grass!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Delightful little nature, your brother.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, he used to have a pony at home. I guess he misses that pony. Is it true that you asked him that?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: To tell me where you were? I confess I wanted very much to know.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, Randolph couldn't tell you. I was having lunch with mother. I thought you were with those ladies.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Whom you saw me with this morning? Oh, no; they've got another cavalier, just arrived, on purpose.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Another cavalier — just arrived? Do you mean that gentleman that speaks so beautifully?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: A dozen languages? His English isn't bad — compared with my French!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, he looks like a cavalier. Did he come on purpose for them?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
What does she know about him?
( Aloud .)
Oh, yes; they sent for him to Geneva.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: To Geneva? That's the one!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: You see, they want him to be always with them; he's for their own particular consumption.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Ah, then he won't come out at two o'clock!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
I'm sure I don't know.
( The bell of the hotel strikes two .)
There it is. You'll have a chance to see.

div.stage: (WINTERBOURNE, on the stroke of the hour, comes out of the hotel .)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Here he comes! He's too sweet!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Oh, I say, she had made an appointment with him while I was doing the mule!

div.stage: (REVERDY, for a moment; DAISY, WINTERBOURNE.)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I am glad to find you: Miss Durant has a particular desire to see you.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
It's very good of you to be her messenger.
