( Aside .)
That's what he calls relieving me!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You will find those ladies in their own sitting-room, on the second floor.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
Oh, I know where it is.
( To DAISY.)
I shall be back in five minutes.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I'm sure you needn't hurry.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I have an idea they have a good deal to say to you.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
I hope it isn't to complain of you!
( Goes into the hotel .)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I was afraid you wouldn't come.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
She has a way of looking at you!
( Aloud .)
I don't know what can have given you such an impression.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, you know, half the time they don't — the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: That's in America, perhaps. But over here they always come.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, I haven't had much experience over here.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it. It was very good of your mother to let you leave her again.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, mother doesn't care; she has got Eugenio.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Surely, not to sit with her?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, he doesn't sit with her always, because he likes to go out.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, he likes to go out!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: He's got a great many friends, Eugenio; he's awfully popular. And then, you know, poor mother isn't very amusing.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Ah, she isn't very amusing!
( Aside .)
Aunt Louisa was right: it isn't the best society!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
But Eugenio stays with her all he can: he says he didn't expect that so much
when he came.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I should think not! I hope at least that it isn't a monopoly, and that I may have the pleasure of making your mother's acquaintance.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, you do speak beautifully! I told Mr. Reverdy.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It was very good of you to mention it. One speaks as one can.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Mother's awfully timid, or else I'd introduce you. She always makes a fuss if I introduce a gentleman. But I do introduce them — the ones I like.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: If it's a sign of your liking, I hope you will introduce me. But you must know my name, which you didn't a while ago.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, Eugenio has told me your name, and I think it's very pretty. And he has told me something else.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I can't imagine what he should tell you about me.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: About you and someone else — that Russian lady who is leaving the hotel.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Who is leaving the hotel! How does he know that?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You see it is true: you are very fond of that Russian lady!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
She is leaving the hotel — but not till six o'clock.
( Aloud .)
I haven't known you very long, but I should like to give you a piece of advice. Don't gossip with your courier!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I see you're offended — and it proves Eugenio was right. He said it was a secret — and you don't like me to know it.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You may know everything, my dear young lady; only don't get your information from a servant.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Do you call Eugenio a servant? He'll be amused if I tell him that!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: He won't be amused — he will be furious; but the particular emotion doesn't matter. It's very good of you to take such an interest.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, I don't know what I should do if I didn't take some interest! You do care for her, then?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
For the Russian lady? Oh, yes, we are old friends.
( Aside .)
My aunt's right: they don't stand the test!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I'm very glad she is going, then. But the others mean to stay?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: The others? What others?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: The two that Mr. Reverdy told me about, and to whom he's so very devoted.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It's my aunt and a friend of hers; but you needn't mind them.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: For all they mind me! But they look stylish.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, yes, they are very stylish; you can bet your life on that, as your brother says!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Did you come for them, or for the Russian lady?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Ah, too many questions!
( Aloud .)
I came for none of them; I came for myself.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Yes, that's the impression you give me: you think a great deal of yourself! But I should like to know your aunt, all the same. She has her hair done like an old picture, and she holds herself so very well; she speaks to no one, and she dines in private. That's the way I should like to be!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah, you would make a bad exchange. My aunt is liable to fearful headaches.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I think she is very elegant — headaches and all! I want very much to know her.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Goodness, what a happy thought!
( Aloud .)
She would be enchanted; only the state of her health ...

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, yes, she has an excuse; that's part of the elegance! I should like to have an excuse. Anyone can see your aunt would have one.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, she has five hundred!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, we haven't any, mother and I. I like a lady to be exclusive. I'm dying to be exclusive myself.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Be just as you are. You wouldn't be half so charming if you were different.
( Aside .)
It's odd how true that is, with all her faults!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
You don't think me charming: you only think me queer. I can see that
by your manner. I should like to know your aunt, anyway

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It's very good of you, I'm sure; but I am afraid those headaches will interfere.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I suppose she doesn't have a headache every day, does she?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
What the deuce is a man to say?
( Aloud .)
She assures me she does.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.stage: ( Turns away a moment, walks to the parapet, and stands there thoughtful .)
sp.p:
She doesn't want to know me!
( Looking at WINTERBOURNE.)
Why don't you say so? You needn't be afraid; I'm not afraid.
( Suddenly, with a little break in her voice .)
Gracious, she is exclusive!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: So much the worse for her!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You see, you've got to own to it! Well, I don't care. I mean to be like that — when I'm old.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I can't think you'll ever be old.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, you horrid thing! As if I were going to perish in my flower!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I should be very sorry if I thought that. But you will never have any quarrel with Time: he'll touch you very gently.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.stage: ( At the parapet, looking over the lake .)
sp.p: I hope I shall never have any quarrel with any one. I'm very good-natured.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You certainly disarm criticism — oh, completely!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
Well, I don't care. Have you ever been to that old castle?
( Pointing to Chillon, in the distance .)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: The Castle of Chillon? Yes, in former days, more than once. I suppose you have been there, too.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, no, we haven't been there. I want to go there awfully. Of course, I mean to go there. I wouldn't go away from here without having seen that old castle!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It's a very pretty excursion, and very easy to make. You can drive, you know, or you can take the little steamer.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, we were going last week, but mother gave out. She suffers terribly from dyspepsia. She said she couldn't go. Randolph won't go, either: he doesn't think much of old castles.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah, your brother isn't interested in historical monuments?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, he's generally disappointed. He wants to stay round here. Mother's afraid to leave him alone, and Eugenio can't be induced to stay with him, so that we haven't been to many places. But it will be too bad if we don't go up to that castle.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I think it might be arranged. Let me see. Couldn't you get some one to remain for the afternoon with Randolph?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, yes; we could get Mr. Reverdy!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Mr. Reverdy?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: He's awfully fond of Randolph; they're always fooling round.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It isn't a bad idea. Reverdy must lay in a stock of sugar.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: There's one thing: with you, mother will be afraid to go.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: She carries her timidity too far! We must wait till she has got used to me.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I don't want to wait. I want to go right off.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah, you can hardly force her to come, you know.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I don't want to force her: I want to leave her!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: To leave her behind? What, then, would you do for an escort?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I would take you.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Me? Me alone?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You seem about as timid as mother! Never mind, I'll take care of you.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Off to Chillon — with you alone — right off?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Right off? Could we go now?

sp.speaker: WINTERBORNE.
sp.p:
She takes away my breath!
( Aloud .)
There's a boat just after three.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: We'll go straight on board!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
She has known me for a couple of hours!
( Aloud, rather formally .)
The privilege for me is immense;
but I feel as if I ought to urge you to reflect a little.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: So as to show how stiff you can be? Oh, I know all about that.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: No, just to remind you that your mother will certainly discover ...

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Will certainly discover?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Your little escapade. You can't hide it.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I don't know what you mean. I have nothing to hide.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Ah, I give it up!
( Seeing EUGENIO, who comes out of the hotel .)
And here comes that odious creature, to spoil it!

div.stage: (WINTERBOURNE, DAISY, EUGENIO.)

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Mademoiselle, your mother requests that you will come to her.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I don't believe a word of it!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
You should not do me the injustice to doubt of my honor! Madame asked me to look for you ten minutes ago; but I was detained by meeting in the hall a lady
( speaking slowly, and looking at WINTERBOURNE)
, a Russian lady, whom I once had the honor to serve, and who was leaving the hotel.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Madame de Katkoff — leaving already?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: She had so many little bags that she could hardly settle herself in the carriage, and I thought it my duty — I have had so much practice — to show her how to stow them away.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Will you kindly excuse me a moment?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
If it's to overtake the Russian lady, Madame de Katkoff is already far away.
( Aside .)
She had four horses: I frightened her more than a little!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Far away — without another word? She can be hard — when she tries. Very good. Let me see if I can be the same!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
Poor man, he's stiffer than ever! But I'm glad she has gone.
( Aloud .)
See here, Eugenio, I'm going to that castle.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Mademoiselle has made arrangements?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, if Mr. Winterbourne doesn't back out.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Back out? I sha'n't be happy till we are off!
( Aside .)
I'll go anywhere — with any one — now; and if the poor girl is injured by it, it isn't my fault!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I think Mademoiselle will find that Madame is in no state —

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: My dear Eugenio, Madame will stay at home with you.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: If she would only not call him her "dear"!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I take the liberty of advising Mademoiselle not to go to the castle.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You had better remember that your place is not to advise, but to look after the little bags!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, I hoped you would make a fuss! But I don't want to go now.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I shall make a fuss if you don't go.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: That's all I want — a little fuss!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: She's not so easy as she would like to appear. She knows it's a risk — but she likes the risk.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: If Mademoiselle will come with me, I will undertake to organize a fuss.

div.stage: ( A steamboat whistle is heard in the distance .)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: The boat's coming up. You have only till three o'clock.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
Oh, I can be quick when I try!
( Hurries into the hotel .)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You had better not interfere with that young lady!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
I suppose you mean that I had better not interfere with you! You had better not defy me to do so!
( Aside .)
It's a pity I sent away the Katkoff!
( Follows DAISY into the hotel .)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
That's a singularly offensive beast! And what the mischief does he mean by his having been in her service? Thank heaven she has got rid of him!
( Seeing MRS. COSTELLO, MISS DURANT, and CHARLES REVERDY, who issue from the hotel, the ladies dressed for a walk .)
Oh, confusion, I had forgotten them!

div.stage: (MRS. COSTELLO, MISS DURANT, CHARLES REVERDY, WINTERBOURNE, then DAISY.)

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Well, Frederick, we take for granted that your little interview is over, and that you are ready to accompany us into the town.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Over, dear aunt? Why, it's only just begun. We are going to the Château de Chillon.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: You and that little girl? You will hardly get us to believe that!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Hang me, why didn't I think of that?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I am afraid I rather incommode you; but I shall be delighted to go into the town when we come back.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: You had better never come back. No one will speak to you!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: My dear Frederick, if you are joking, your joke is in dreadful taste.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I am not joking, in the least. The young lady is to be here at three.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: She herself is joking, then. She won't be so crazy as to come.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.stage: ( Who has gone to the parapet and looked off to right, coming back, taking out his watch .)
sp.p: It's close upon three, and the boat's at the wharf.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Not quite yet. Give her a moment's grace.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: It won't be for us to give her grace: it will be for society.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah, but you are society, you know. She wants immensely to know you.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Is that why she is flinging herself at you?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Listen to me seriously, please. The poor little girl has given me a great mark — a very touching mark — of confidence. I wish to present her to you, because I wish someone to answer for my honor.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: And pray, who is to answer for hers?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, I say, you're cruel!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I am an old woman, Frederick; but I thank my stars I am not too old to be horrified!

div.stage: ( The bell of the steamboat is heard to ring in the distance .)

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: There's your boat, sir. I'm afraid you'll miss it!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Three o'clock. Damn that courier!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: If she doesn't come, you may present her.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: She won't come. We must do her justice.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
I say, Mr. Winterbourne, I'm as punctual as you!
( She wears a charming travelling-dress, and is buttoning her glove . EUGENIO appears in the porch of the hotel, and stands there, with his hands in his pockets, and with a baffled but vindictive air, watching the rest of the scene .)

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Alas, the presentation's gone!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Gracious, how they glare at me!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Take my arm. The boat's at the wharf.
( She takes his arm, and they hasten away, passing through the little gate of the parapet, where they descend and disappear. The bell of the steamer continues to ring . MRS. COSTELLO and her companions have watched them; as they vanish, she and MISS DURANT each drop into a chair .)

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: They will never come back!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Isn't it your duty to go after them?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: They will be lovely company for the rest of the day!

div.head: ACT SECOND
div.stage: A beautiful afternoon in the gardens of the Pincian Hill in Rome. A view of St. Peter's in the distance .
(WINTERBOURNE, MADAME DE KATKOFF, meeting from opposite sides. He stands before her a moment, and kisses her hand .)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: When, at your hotel just now, they told me you had gone out, I was pretty sure you had come here.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I always come here as soon as I arrive in Rome, for the sake of that view. It's an old friend of mine.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Have you no old friends but that, and wasn't it also — a little — for the sake of meeting one or two of them? We all come here, you know.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: One or two of them? You don't mean two — you mean one! I knew you all come here, and that's why I have arrived early, before the crowd and the music.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: That's what I was counting on. I know your tastes. I wanted to find you alone.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Being alone with you isn't one of my tastes! If I had known I should meet you, I think I shouldn't have left my carriage.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: If it's there, at hand, you might invite me to get into it.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I have sent it away for half an hour, while I stretch myself a little. I have been sitting down for a week — in railway-trains.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You can't escape from me, then!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Don't begin that way, or you'll disappoint me. You speak as if you had received none of my letters.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: And you speak as if you had written me a dozen! I received three little notes.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: They were short, but they were clear.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, very clear indeed! "You're an awful nuisance, and I wish never to hear of you again." That was about the gist of them.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: "Unless you promise not to persecute me, I won't come to Rome." That's more how I should express it. And you did promise.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I promised to try and hate you, for that seemed to be what you wished to bring me to! And I have been waiting for you these three weeks, as a man waits for his worst enemy.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I should be your worst enemy indeed, if I listened to you — if I allowed you to mingle your fresh, independent life with my own embarrassed and disillusioned one. If you have been here three weeks, you ought to have found some profitable occupation.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You speak as if I were looking out for a job! My principal occupation has been waiting for you.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It must have made you pleasant company to your friends.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: My friends are only my aunt and the young lady who is with her — a very good girl, but painfully prim. I have been devoted to them, because I said to myself that after you came —

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You wouldn't have possession of your senses? So it appears. On the same principle, I hope you have shown some attention to the little girl who was at Vevey, whom I saw you in such a fair way to be intimate with.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: What do you know about her?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Nothing but that we are again at the same hotel. A former servant of mine, a very unprincipled fellow, is now in her mother's employ, and he was the first person I met as I left my rooms to-day. I imagine from this that the young lady is not far off.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Not far off from him . I wish she were farther!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: She struck me last summer as remarkably attractive.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: She's exactly what she was last summer — only more so!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: She must be quite enchanting, then.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Do you wish me to fall in love with her?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It would give me particular pleasure. I would go so far as to be the confidant of your passion.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I have no passion to confide. She's a little American flirt.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It seems to me there is a certain passion in that!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: She's foolish, frivolous, futile. She is making herself terribly talked about.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
She looked to me very
innocent — with those eyes!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, yes, I made a great deal of those eyes — they have the most charming lashes. But they look at too many people.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Should you like them to fix themselves on you? You're rather difficult to please. The young lady with your aunt is too grave, and this poor little person is too gay! You had better find someone who's between the two.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You are between the two, and you won't listen to me.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I think I understand your country-people better than you do. I have learned a good deal about them from my observation of yourself.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: That must have made you very fond of them!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It has made me feel very kindly toward them, as you see from my interest in those young ladies. Don't judge them by what they seem. They are probably just the opposite, for that is precisely the case with yourself. Most people think you very cold, but I have discovered the truth. You are like one of those tall German stoves, which present to the eye a surface of smooth white porcelain, without the slightest symptom of fuel or of flame. Nothing at first could seem less glowing; but after you have been in the room with it for half an hour you feel that the temperature is rising — and you want to open a window!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: A tall German stove — that's a very graceful comparison.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I am sure your grave young lady is very gay.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It doesn't matter; she has got a young man of her own.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: The young man who was always with them? If you are going to be put off by a rival, I have nothing to say.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: He's not a rival of mine; he's only a rival of my aunt's. She wants me to marry Miss Durant, but Miss Durant prefers the gallant Reverdy.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: That simplifies it.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Not so very much; because the gallant Reverdy shows a predilection for Miss Daisy Miller.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Ah, then he is your rival!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: There are so many others that he doesn't count. She has at least a dozen admirers, and she knocks about Rome with all of them. She once told me that she was very fond of gentlemen's society; but unfortunately they are not all gentlemen.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: So much the better chance for you.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: She doesn't know, she can't distinguish. She is incredibly light.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It seems to me that you express yourself with a certain bitterness.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I am not in the least in love with her, if that's what you mean. But simply as an outsider, as a spectator, as an American, I can't bear to see a nice girl — if she is a nice girl — expose herself to the most odious misconception. That is, if she is a nice girl!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: By my little system, she ought to be very nice. If she seems very wild, depend upon it she is very tame.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: She has produced a fearful amount of scandal.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: That proves she has nothing to hide. The wicked ones are not found out!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: She has nothing to hide but her mother, whom she conceals so effectually that no mortal eye has beheld her. Miss Daisy goes to parties alone! When I say alone, I mean that she is usually accompanied by a foreigner with a waxed moustache and a great deal of manner. She is too nice for a foreigner!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: As a Russian, I am greatly obliged to you!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: This isn't a Russian. He's a Roman — the Cavaliere Giovanelli.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You spoke of a dozen, and now you have settled down to one.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: There were a dozen at first, but she picked them over and selected. She has made a mistake, because the man she has chosen is an adventurer.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: An adventurer?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Oh, a very plausible one. He is very good-looking, very polite; he sings little songs at parties. He comes of a respectable family, but he has squandered
his small patrimony, and he has no means of subsistence but his personal charms, which he has been hoping for the last ten years will endear him to some susceptible American heiress — whom he flatters himself he has found at last!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You ought to advise her — to put her on her guard.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, she's not serious; she is only amusing herself.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Try and make her serious. That's a mission for an honest man!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It's so odd to hear you defending her! It only puzzles me the more.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You ought to understand your countrywomen better.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: My countrywomen?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I don't mean me: I mean Miss Daisy Miller.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It seems very stupid, I confess; but I have lived so long in foreign parts, among people of different manners. I mean, however, to settle the question to-day and to make up my mind. I shall meet Miss Daisy at four o'clock. I have promised to go to Mrs. Walker's.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: And pray who is Mrs. Walker?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: The wife of the American consul — a very good-natured woman, who has a passion for afternoon-tea. She took up Miss Daisy when they came; she used to call her the little Flower of the West. But now she's holding the little flower in her fingertips, at arm's length, trying to decide to let it drop.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Poor little flower! It must be four o'clock now.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You're in a great hurry to get rid of me! Mrs. Walker's is close at hand, just beyond the Spanish Steps. I shall have time to stroll round the Pincian with you.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I have had strolling enough. I shall wait for my carriage.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Let me at least come and see you this evening.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I should be delighted, but I am going to the opera.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Already? The first night you are here?

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It's not the first; it's the second. I am very fond of music.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It's always bad in Italy.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I have made provision against that in the person of the Russian ambassador, whom I have asked to come into my box.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Ah, with ambassadors I stand no chance.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
You are the greatest diplomatist of all! Good-by for the present.
( She turns away . WINTERBOURNE looks after her a moment .)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You decide more easily than Mrs. Walker: you have dropped me!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
Ah, but you're not a flower!
(WINTERBOURNE looks at her an instant longer; then, with a little passionate switch of his stick, he walks off. Just as he disappears , EUGENIO comes in at the back .)
And now I shall have a quiet evening with a book!

div.stage: (MADAME DE KATKOFF, EUGENIO, who enters hat in hand, with a bow .)

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: It's the second time to-day that I have had the pleasure of meeting Madame.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I should like very much to believe it would be the last!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: That, perhaps, is more than I can promise. We will call it the last but one; for my purpose in approaching Madame is to demand an interview — a serious interview! Seeing Madame, at a distance, in conversation with a gentleman, I waited till the gentleman had retired; for I must do Madame the justice to admit that, with Madame, the gentlemen do usually, at last, retire!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It's a misfortune to me, since they leave me exposed!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Madame is not exposed; Madame is protected. So long as I have an eye on Madame, I can answer for it that she will suffer no injury.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You protect me as the butcher protects the lamb! I suppose you have come to name your price.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Madame goes straight to the point! I have come to name my price, but not to ask for money.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It's very kind of you to recognize that I have not money enough.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Madame has money enough, but the talents of Madame are still greater than her wealth. It is with the aid of these talents that I shall invite Madame to render me a service — a difficult, delicate service, but so valuable that it will release Madame from further obligations.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: It's delightful to think of being released! I suppose the service is to recommend you as a domestic. That would be difficult, certainly.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Too difficult — for Madame! No; it is simply, as I say, to grant me an interview, when I can explain. Be so good as to name an hour when I can wait upon you.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: In my apartments? I would rather not see you there. Explain to me here.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: It's a little delicate for a public place. Besides, I have another appointment here.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You do a great business! If you mean that I am to wait upon you , we may as well drop negotiations.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Let us compromise. My appointment will end in a quarter of an hour. If at that time Madame is still on the Pincian —

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You would like me to sit upon a bench till you are ready to attend to me?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: It would have the merit of settling the matter at once, without more suspense for Madame.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
That would be a merit, certainly; and I am curious about the exercise he wishes to offer my talents!
( Aloud .)
I shall stroll about here till my carriage comes; if you wish to take advantage of that —

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: To take advantage is exactly what I wish! And as this particular spot is exceptionally quiet I shall look for Madame here.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: How unspeakably odious!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.stage: ( Alone a moment, looking after her .)
sp.p:
She shall bend till she breaks! The delay will have the merit, too, of making me sure of Giovanelli — if he only keeps the tryst! I mustn't throw away a card on her before I've won the game of him. But he's such a deuced fine gentleman that there's no playing fair!
( Seeing GIOVANELLI, who comes in at the left .)
He is up to time, though.
( Bowing .)
Signor Cavaliere!

div.stage: (EUGENIO, GIOVANELLI.)

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.stage: ( Very elegant, with flowers in his buttonhole; cautious, looking round him .)
sp.p: You might have proposed meeting in some less conspicuous spot!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: In the Coliseum, at midnight? My dear sir, we should be much more compromised if we were discovered there!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Oh, if you count upon our being discovered! ...

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: There is nothing so unnatural in our having a little conversation. One should never be ashamed of an accomplice!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Don't speak of accomplices: as if we were concocting a crime!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: What makes it a work of merit is my conviction that you are a perfect gentleman. If it hadn't been for that, I never should have presented you to my family.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Your family? You speak as if, in marrying the girl, I should become your brother-in-law.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: We shall certainly be united by a very peculiar tie!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p:
United — united? I don't know about that! After my marriage, I shall travel without a courier.
( Smiling .)
It will be less expensive!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: In the event you speak of, I myself hardly expect to remain in the ranks. I have seen too many campaigns: I shall retire on my pension. You look as if you did not understand me.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Perfectly. You expect the good Mrs. Miller to make you comfortable for the rest of your days.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
What I expect of the good Mrs. Miller is one thing; what I expect of you is another: and on that point we had better be perfectly clear. It was to insure perfect clearness that I proposed this little conference, which you refused to allow to
take place either in your own lodgings or in some comfortable café. Oh, I know you had your reasons! You don't exhibit your little interior; and though I know a good deal about you, I don't know where you live. It doesn't matter, I don't want to know: it's enough for me that I can always find you here, amid the music and the flowers. But I can't exactly make out why you wouldn't meet me at a café. I would gladly have paid for a glass of beer.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: It was just your beer I was afraid of! I never touch the beastly stuff.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Ah, if you drink nothing but champagne, no wonder you are looking for an heiress! But before I help you to one, let me give you a word of advice. Make the best of me, if you wish me to make the best of you. I was determined to do that when I presented you to the two most amiable women in the world.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: I must protest against your theory that you presented me. I met Mrs. Miller at a party, as any gentleman might have done.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: You met her at a party, precisely; but unless I wish it, Mrs. Miller doesn't go to a party! I let you know she was to be there, and I advised you how to proceed. For the last three weeks I have done nothing but arrange little accidents, little surprises, little occasions, of which I will do you the justice to say that you have taken excellent advantage. But the time has come when I must remind you that I have not done all this from mere admiration of your distinguished appearance. I wish your success to be my success!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: I am glad to hear you talk about my success!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Oh, there's a good deal to be said about it! Have you ever been to the circus?

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: I don't see what that has to do with it!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: You've seen the bareback rider turn a somersault through the paper hoops? It's a very pretty feat, and it brings him great applause; but half the effect depends upon the poor devil — whom no one notices — who is perched upon the edge of the ring. If he didn't hold the hoop with a great deal of skill, the bareback rider would simply come down on his nose. You turn your little somersaults, Signor Cavaliere, and my young lady claps her hands; but all the while I 'm holding the hoop!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: If I'm not mistaken, that office, at the circus, is usually performed by the clown.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Take very good care, or you'll have a fall!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: I suppose you want to be paid for your trouble.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: The point isn't that I want to be paid: that goes without saying! But I want to be paid handsomely.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: What do you call handsomely?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
A commission proportionate to the fortune of the young lady. I know something about that. I have in my pocket
( slapping his side )
the letter of credit of the Signora. She lets me carry it — for safety's sake!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Poor Signora! It's a strange game we are playing!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Oh, if you doubt of the purity of your motives, you have only to say so. You swore to me that you adored my young lady.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: She's an angel, and I worship the ground she treads on. That makes me wonder whether I couldn't get on without you.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Try it and see. I have only to say the word, and Mrs. Miller will start to-morrow for the north.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: And if you don't say the word, that's another thing you want to be paid for! It mounts up very fast.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: It mounts up to fifty thousand francs, to be handed to me six months after you are married.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Fifty thousand francs?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: The family exchequer will never miss them. Besides, I give you six months. You sign a little note, "for value received."

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: And if the marriage — if the marriage —

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: If the marriage comes to grief, I burn up the note.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: How can I be sure of that?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
By having already perceived
that I'm not an idiot. If you don't marry, you can't pay: I need no one to tell me that. But I intend you shall marry.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: It's uncommonly good of you! After all, I haven't a squint!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I picked you out for your good looks; and you're so tremendously fascinating that even when I lose patience with your want of everything else I can't afford to sacrifice you. Your prospects are now very good. The estimable mother —

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: The estimable mother believes me to be already engaged to her daughter. It shows how much she knows about it!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
No, you are not engaged, but you will be, next week. You have rather too many flowers there, by the way: you overdo it a little.
( Pointing to GIOVANELLI'S buttonhole .)

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: So long as you pay for them, the more the better! How far will it carry me to be engaged? Mr. Miller can hardly be such a fool as his wife.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Mr. Miller?

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: The mysterious father, in that unpronounceable town! He must be a man of energy, to have made such a fortune, and the idea of his energy haunts me!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: That's because you've got none yourself.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: I don't pretend to that; I only pretend to — a —

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: To be fascinating, I know! But you're afraid the papa won't see it.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: I don't exactly see why he should set his heart on a Roman son-in-law.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: It's your business to produce that miracle!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: By making the girl talked about? My respect for her is in proportion to the confidence she shows me. That confidence is unlimited.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Oh, unlimited! I have never seen anything like that confidence; and if out of such a piece of cloth as that you can't cut a coat —

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: I never pretended to be a tailor! And you must not forget that I have a rival.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Forget it? I regard it as a particularly gratifying fact. If you didn't have a rival I should have very small hopes of you.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: I confess I don't follow you. The young lady's confidence in Mr. Winterbourne is at least equal to her confidence in me.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Ah, but his confidence in the young lady? That's another affair! He thinks she goes too far. He's an American, like herself; but there are Americans and Americans, and when they take it into their heads to open their eyes they open them very wide.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: If you mean that this American's a donkey, I see no reason to differ with you.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Leave him to me. I've got a stick to beat him with!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: You make me shiver a little! Do you mean to put him out of the way?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I mean to put him out of the way. Ah, you can trust me! I don't carry a stiletto, and if you'll excuse me I won't describe my little plan. You'll tell me what you think of it when you have seen the results. The great feature is simply that Miss Daisy, seeing herself abandoned —

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Will look about her for a consoler? Ah, consolation is a specialty of mine, and if you give me a chance to console I think I shall be safe.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
I shall go to work on the spot!
( Takes out his pocket-book, from which he extracts a small folded paper, holding it up a moment before GIOVANELLI.)
Put your name to that, and send it back to me by post.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.stage: ( Reading the paper with a little grimace .)
sp.p: Fifty thousand! Fifty thousand is steep.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Signor Cavaliere, the letter of credit is for half a million!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p:
Well, give me a chance to console — give me a chance to console!
( Goes off at the back, while, at the same moment , MME. DE KATKOFF reappears .)

div.stage: (EUGENIO, MADAME DE KATKOFF.)

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
The Katkoff — up to time! If my second little paper works as well as my first, I have nothing to fear.
( Aloud .)
I am quite at the service of Madame.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: My carriage has not come back; it was to pick up a friend at St. Peter's.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I am greatly indebted to Madame's friends. I have my little proposition ready.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Be so good as to let me hear it.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: In three words it is this: Do me the favor to captivate Mr. Winterbourne! Madame starts a little. She will pretend, perhaps, that Mr. Winterbourne is already captivated.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: You have an odd idea of my pretensions! I would rather pay you a sum of money than listen to this sort of thing.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: I was afraid you would be a little shocked — at first. But the proposal I make has the greatest recommendations.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: For Mr. Winterbourne, certainly!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: For Mr. Winterbourne, very plainly; but also for Madame, if she would only reflect upon the facility —

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: What do you know about facility? Your proposal is odious!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: The worst is already done. Mr. Winterbourne is deeply interested in Madame.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: His name has no place in our discussion. Be so good as not to mention it again.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: It will be easy not to mention it: Madame will understand without that. She will remember, perhaps, that when I had the honor of meeting her last summer, I was in the service of a distinguished family.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: The amiable Mrs. Miller? That name has stuck in my mind!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Permit me to regard it as a happy omen! The amiable Mrs. Miller, as I then informed Madame, has a daughter as amiable as herself. It is of the greatest importance that this young lady should be detached from the gentleman whose name I am not allowed to mention.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Should be detached?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: If he is interested in Madame, he is also a little interested in the Signorina. You know what men are, Madame!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: If the Signorina is as amiable as you say, I can imagine no happier circumstance.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: From the point of view of Madame, who is a little tired of the gentleman; but not from my own, who wish the young lady to make another marriage.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: Excuse me from entering into your points of view and your marriages!

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
Ah, if you choose to terminate the discussion, it wasn't worth while to wait.
( A pause .)

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
It was worth while to wait — to learn what a coward I am!
( Aloud, after a moment .)
Is Miss Miller in love with Mr. Winterbourne?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
I thought Madame would come to the name!
( Aside .)
It was the idea that fetched her!
( Aloud .)
Miss Miller is not, perhaps, exactly in love with Mr. Winterbourne, but she has a great appreciation of his society. What I ask of you is to undertake that for the next two months she shall have as little of it as possible.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: By taking as much of it myself? You ask me to play a very pretty part.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: Madame would play it to perfection!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: To break a young girl's heart — to act an abominable comedy?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: You won't break any one's heart, unless it be Mr. Winterbourne's — which will serve him right for being so tiresome. As for the comedy, remember that the best actresses receive the highest salary.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: If I had been a good actress, you never would have got me into your power. What do you propose to do with your little American?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
To marry her to a Roman gentleman. All I ask of you is to use a power you already have. I know that of late it has suited your pleasure not to use it: you have tried to keep Mr. Winterbourne at a distance. But call him a little nearer,
and you will see that he will come!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: So that the girl may see it too? Your ingenuity does you great honor. I don't believe in your Roman gentleman.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p: It is not necessary that you should believe. Believe only that on the day the Signorina becomes engaged to the irreproachable person I have selected, I will place in your hands the document which I hold at your disposition.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: How am I to be sure of that?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
They all want to be sure!
( Aloud .)
Nothing venture, nothing have!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: And if she never becomes engaged?

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
Ah, then, I confess, I must still hold the document.
( Aside .)
That will make her work for it!
( Aloud .)
Why should you trouble yourself with irrelevant questions? Your task is perfectly definite. Occupy Mr. Winterbourne, and leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p: I must tell you — disagreeable as it may be to me to do so — that I shall have to make a very sudden turn.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
It will be all the more effective.
( Complacently .)
Sudden turns are the essence of fascination!

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
It's insufferable to discuss with him! But if there's a hope — if there's a hope ...
( Aloud .)
I told Mr. Winterbourne, not an hour ago, that I wished never to see him again.

sp.speaker: EUGENIO.
sp.p:
I can imagine no more agreeable surprise to him, then, than to be told, half an hour hence, that you can't live without him! You know the things the ladies say! Don't be afraid of being sudden: he'll think it the more romantic. For you those things are easy, Madame
( bowing low );
for you those things are easy. I leave the matter to your consideration.
( Aside, as he goes off .)
She'll do it!
( Exit .)

sp.speaker: MME. DE KATKOFF.
sp.p:
Those things are easy — those things are easy? They are easier, perhaps, than paying out half one's fortune.
( Stands a moment thoughtful, then gives a little nervous gesture, as of decision .)
If I give him leave to come to the opera, I must go myself — to Italian music! But an hour or two of Donizetti, for the sake of one's comfort! ... He said he would come back — from the wife of the consul.
( Looking about her, she goes out .)

div.stage: (DAISY, then GIOVANELLI.)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.stage: ( Coming in with a certain haste, and glancing behind her .)
sp.p:
It's a pity you can't walk in Rome without everyone staring so! And now he's not here — he's not where he said he would be. I don't care. He's very nice, but I certainly shan't go and look for him. I'll just wait a little. Perhaps, if I don't walk round, they won't stare at me so much. I didn't say good-by to Mrs. Walker, because she was talking to Mr. Winterbourne, and I shan't go near Mr. Winterbourne again till he comes near me. Half an hour in the room, and never within ten yards of me! He looks so pleasant when he talks — even when he talks to other girls. He's always talking to other girls, and not even to girls — to old women, and gentlemen, and foreigners. I've done something he doesn't like, I'm very sure of that. He doesn't like anything — anything that I do. It's hard to know what he does like! He's got such peculiar tastes — from his foreign education; you can't ever tell where you'll find him. Well, I haven't had a foreign education, and I don't see that I'm any the worse for that. If I'd had a foreign education, I might as well give up! I shouldn't be able to breathe, for fear I was breathing wrong. There seem to be so many ways, over here! But I only know one way, and I don't see why I should learn the others when there are people who do like — who do like — what I do. They say they do, at any rate, and they say it so prettily! The English say it very nicely, but the Italians say it best. As for the Americans, they don't say it at all, and Mr. Winterbourne less than any of them! Well, I don't care so much about the Americans: I can make it all right with the Americans when I get home. Mr. Winterbourne isn't an American; I never saw any one like him over there. If I had, perhaps I shouldn't have come away; for over there
it would all be different. Well, it isn't different here, and I suppose it never will be. Everything is strange over here; and what is strangest of all is one's liking people that are so peculiar.
( Stands thoughtful a moment, then rouses herself .)
There's Mr. Giovanelli — a mile off. Does he suppose I wish to communicate with him by signs?

div.stage: (GIOVANELLI comes in, hat in hand, with much eagerness .)

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: I have looked for you everywhere!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, I wasn't everywhere; I was here.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Standing all alone, without a protector!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I wasn't more alone than I was at Mrs. Walker's.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Because I was not there?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
Oh, it wasn't the people who were not there!
( Aside .)
If they had known I was coming, I suppose there wouldn't have been anyone!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.stage: ( In an attitude of the most respectful admiration .)
sp.p: How can I sufficiently thank you for granting me this supreme satisfaction?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: That's a very fine name to give to a walk on the Pincian. You had better put on your hat.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: You wish to escape notice? Perhaps you are right. That was why I didn't come to Mrs. Walker's, whose parties are so charming! I thought that if we slipped away together it might attract attention.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Do you mean they would have thought it improper? They would have thought it still more improper to see me leaving alone; so I didn't say a word to any one — only mother.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Ah, you told your admirable parent? She is with us, then, in spirit!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: She wanted to get away herself, if that's what you mean; but she didn't feel as if she could leave till Eugenio came for her. And Eugenio seems to have so much to do to-day.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: It is doubtless in your interest. He is a very faithful servant.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Well, he told mother she must stay there an hour: he had some business of importance.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Let us hope that his business is done, and that the patient Mrs. Miller is released.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: She was patient enough when I told her I shouldn't come to dinner.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.stage: ( Starting, with an air of renewed devotion .)
sp.p: Am I to understand that you have consented to my little fantasy?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Of dining at that old tavern, where the artists go?

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: The renowned and delightful Falcone , in the heart of ancient Rome! You are a person of delicious surprises! The other day, you wouldn't listen to it.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
I don't remember the other day: all I know is, I'll go now.
( Aside .)
The other day Mr. Winterbourne spoke to me!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: My dear young lady, you make me very happy!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: By going to eat macaroni with you?

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: It isn't the macaroni; it's the sentiment!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: The sentiment is yours, not mine. I haven't any: it's all gone!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Well, I shan't complain if I find myself at table with you in a dusky corner of that picturesque little cook-shop, where the ceiling is black, and the walls are brown, and the floor is red!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.stage: ( Watching him as he describes it .)
sp.p: Oh dear! it must be very lovely.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: And the old wine-flasks, covered with plaited straw, are as big round — are much bigger round — than your waist!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: That's just what I want to see. Let's go there at once!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Half-past four. Isn't that rather soon to dine?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: We can go on foot through the old streets. I'm dying to see them on foot.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p:
That will be cheaper than a cab!
( Aloud .)
We should get there at five — a little early still. Mightn't we first take a few turns round this place?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, yes, if you like.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p:
I should like my
creditors to see!
( Aloud .)
Perhaps it doesn't suit you: you are a little afraid.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: What should I be afraid of?

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Not of meeting your mother, I know!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: If I had been afraid, I shouldn't have come.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: That is perfect. But let me say one thing: you have a way of taking the meaning from the favors you bestow.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: The meaning? They haven't got any meaning!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: Ah!

div.stage: (MRS. COSTELLO, MISS DURANT, and CHARLES REVERDY appear .)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.stage: ( Looking at MRS. COSTELLO and MISS DURANT.)
sp.p: Unless it be to make those dreadful women glower. How d'ye do, Mr. Reverdy?

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p:
I see you are not afraid!
( He goes out with her .)

div.stage: (MRS. COSTELLO, MISS DURANT, CHARLES REVERDY.)

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: She has grown to look very hard.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: The gentleman looks soft, and that makes up for it.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Do you call him a gentleman?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Ah, compared with the courier! She has a different one every time.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: A different one every time, but never, alas, this one!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: There's one comfort in it all: she has given up Frederick.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Ah, she goes too far even for him!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Too far with other men: that's the trouble! With him she went as far as the Castle of Chillon.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Don't recall that episode. Heaven only knows what happened there.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: I know what happened: he was awfully sold. That's why he let you carry him off.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Much good it did us! I'm very much disappointed in Frederick.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I can't imagine what you expected of him.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I expected him to fall in love with you — or to marry you, at any rate.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: You would have been still more disappointed, then, if I had refused him.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I should have been surprised.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Would you have refused him, Miss Durant?

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Yes, on purpose to spite you. You don't understand? It takes a man to be stupid! If Mr. Winterbourne were to marry some one else, it would leave Miss Daisy Miller free.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Free to walk about with the native population? She seems to be free enough already. Mrs. Costello, the campstool is at your service.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p:
Give it to me, and I will go and sit in the shade. Excuse me, I would rather carry it myself.
( Taking the camp-stool, aside to MISS DURANT.)
If he proposes, mind you accept him.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: If who proposes?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p:
Our young companion! He is manoeuvring to get rid of me. He has nothing but his expectations, but his expectations are of the best.
( She marches away with her camp-stool, and seats herself at a distance, where, with her eyeglass raised, she appears to look at what goes on in another part of the garden .)

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p:
Am I one of his expectations? Fortunately, I don't need to marry for money.
( Aloud .)
Cousin Louisa is furious with me for not being more encouraging to Mr. Winterbourne. I don't know what she would have liked me to do!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: You have been very proper, very dignified.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: That's the way I was brought up. I never liked him, from the first.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Oh, he's a stupid stick!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I don't say he's stupid — and he's very good-looking.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: As good-looking as a man can be in whom one feature — the most expressive — has been entirely omitted. He has got no eyes in his head.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: No eyes?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: To see that that poor little creature is in love with him.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: She has a queer way of showing it.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Ah, they always have queer ways!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: He sees it, but he doesn't care.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
That's still worse, — the omission not of a feature, but of an organ
( tapping his heart and smiling ),
the seat of our purest and highest joys!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p:
Cousin Louisa was right!
( Aloud .)
Do you mean that he has no heart?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: If he had as big a one as the rosette on your shoe, would he leave me here to do all the work?

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: The rosette on my shoe is rather big.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: It isn't so much the size of the rosette as the smallness of the shoe!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p:
Cousin Louisa is certainly right!
( Aloud, smiling .)
Yours, I suppose, is bigger than that.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: My shoe? I should think so — rather!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Dear, no! I mean your heart. Though I don't think it's at all nice in you to complain of being left with us.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
When I am left with you, I don't complain; but when I am left with her!
( Indicating MRS. COSTELLO.)

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Well, you are not with her now.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Ah, now it's very pleasant. Only she has got the camp-stool.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Do you want it for yourself?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Yes; I have been carrying it for the last six months, and I feel rather awkward without it. It gives one confidence to have something in one's hand.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Good heavens! What do you want to do?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: I want to make you a little speech.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: You will do very well as you are.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
I'll try it.
( In an attitude .)
Six months ago I had moments of rebellion, but to-day I have come to love my chains! Accordingly —
(MRS. COSTELLO starts up and hurries forward, the camp-stool in her hand .)
By Jove! if she hears me, she'll rivet them faster.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: My poor, dear child, whom do you think I've seen?

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: By your expression, the ghost of Julius Cæsar!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: The Russian woman — the princess — whom we saw last summer.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Well, my dear cousin, she won't eat us up!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: No, but she'll eat Frederick!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: On the contrary, her appetite for Frederick is small. Don't you remember that, last summer, she left the hotel as soon as he arrived?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: That was only a feint, to put us off the scent. He has been in secret correspondence with her, and their meeting here is prearranged.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: I don't know why you call their correspondence secret, when he was always going to the post-office!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Ah, but you can't tell what he did there! Frederick is very deep.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: There's nothing secret, at any rate, about her arrival here. She alighted yesterday at our own hotel, in the most public manner, with the landlord and all the waiters drawn up to receive her. It didn't occur to me to mention it.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: I don't really know what you are with us for!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Oh, Cousin Louisa, he is meant for better things than that!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Do you mean that he has proposed?

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: No, but he was just going to.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Ah, you have told me that before!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Because you never give him time.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Does he want three hours?

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: No, but he wants three minutes!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.stage: ( Who has strolled away, observing them, aside .)
sp.p:
Happy thought, to make them fight about me! Mutual destruction would ensue, and I should be master of the situation.
( Aloud .)
I am only
a man, dear Madam; I am not a newspaper.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: If you only were, we could stop our subscription! And, as a proof of what I say, here comes Frederick, to look after his Russian.

div.stage: (WINTERBOURNE comes in, with MRS. WALKER.)

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: With the wife of the consul, to look after him!

div.stage: (MRS. COSTELLO, MISS DURANT, REVERDY, WINTERBOURNE, MRS. WALKER.)

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: Oh, you dreadful people, what are you doing here, when you ought to be at my reception?

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: We were just thinking of going; it's so very near.

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: Only round the corner! But there are better reasons than that.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: There can hardly be a very good one, when you yourself have come away!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: You would never imagine what has brought me! I have come in pursuit of little Daisy Miller.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: And you have brought my nephew to help you!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: A walk in such charming company is a privilege not to be lost. Perhaps, dear aunt, you can give us news.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Of that audacious and desperate person? Dear me, yes. We met her just now, on the arm of a dreadful man.

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: Oh, we are too late then. She is lost!

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p:
It seems to me she was lost long ago, and
( significantly, at WINTERBOURNE)
that this is not the first rendezvous she has taken.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: If it does her no more harm than the others, Mrs. Walker had better go back to her teapot!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: That's an allusion to the way he was sold!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: She left my house, half an hour ago, without a word to anyone but her idiot of a mother, who thought it all right that she should walk off to the Pincian to meet the handsome Giovanelli. I only discovered her flight just now, by a lady who was coming in at the moment that Miss Daisy, shaking out her little flounces and tossing up her little head, tripped away from my door, to fall into the arms of a cavalier!

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: Into his arms? Ah, Mrs. Walker!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: My dear young lady, with these unscrupulous foreigners one can never be sure. You know as well as I what becomes of the reputation of a girl who shows herself in this place, at this hour, with all the rank and fashion of Rome about her, with no more responsible escort than a gentleman renowned for his successes!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: It's as if you were here with me, you know!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: This idea came over me with a kind of horror, and I determined to save her if I could.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: There is nothing left of her to save!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: There is always something left, and my representative position makes it a duty. My rooms were filled with guests — a hundred and fifty people — but I put on my bonnet and seized Mr. Winterbourne's arm.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You can testify that I didn't wince! I quite agree with you as to the importance of looking her up. Foreigners never understand.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: My dear fellow, if they understand no better than you! ...

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: What I want of you dear people is to go and entertain my visitors. Console them for my absence, and tell them I shall be back in five minutes.

sp.speaker: MISS DURANT.
sp.p: It will be very nice to give a reception without any trouble.

sp.speaker: MRS. COSTELLO.
sp.p: Without any trouble — scarcely! But there is nothing we wouldn't do —

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p:
For the representative of one's country! Be charming, then, as you can so well.
( Seeing DAISY and GIOVANELLI come in .)
I shall not be long, for by the mercy of Heaven the child is guided to this spot!

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p:
If you think you have only to pick her up, we won't wait for you!
( He goes out with MRS. COSTELLO and MISS DURANT.)

div.stage: (MRS. WALKER, WINTERBOURNE, DAISY, GIOVANELLI.)

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.stage: ( As the two others slowly come in together, not at first seeing him .)
sp.p: We shall have a siege: she won't give him up for the asking.

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: We must divide our forces, then. You will deal with Daisy.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I would rather attack the gentleman.

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: No, no; there'll be trouble. Mr. Giovanelli, I should like a little conversation with you.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.stage: ( Starting, and coming forward; very polite .)
sp.p: You do me great honor, Madame!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p:
I wish to scold you for not coming to me to-day; but to spare your blushes, it must be in private.
( Strolls away with him, out of sight .)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: They have come to take me away. Ah, they are very cruel!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I had no chance to speak to you at Mrs. Walker's, and I have come to make up for my loss.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: What is Mrs. Walker doing here! Why doesn't she stay with her guests?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I brought her away — to do just what she has done.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: To take away Mr. Giovanelli? I don't understand you.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: A great many people think that you understand, but that you don't care.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I don't care what people think. I have done no harm.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: That's exactly what I say — you don't care. But I wish you would care a little, for your friends are very much frightened. When Mrs. Walker ascertained that you had left her house alone, and had come to meet a gentleman here — here, where all Rome assembles at this hour to amuse itself, and where you would be watched and criticised and calumniated — when Mrs. Walker made this discovery, she said but three words — "To the rescue!" But she took her plunge, as if you had been drowning.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: And you jumped overboard, too!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh dear, no; I'm standing on the brink. I only interpret her sentiments. I don't express my own.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: They would interest me more than Mrs. Walker's; but I don't see what either of you have to do with me.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: We admire you very much, and we hate to see you misjudged.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I don't know what you mean, and I don't know what you think I want to do.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I haven't the least idea about that. All I mean is that if you could see, as I see it, how little it's the custom here to do what you do, and how badly it looks to fly in the face of the custom, you would be a little more on your guard.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I know nothing about the custom. I'm an American; I'm not one of these people.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: In that case, you would behave differently. Your being an American is just the point. You are a very conspicuous American, thanks to your attractions, to your charms, to the publicity of your life. Such people, with the best intentions in the world, are often very indiscreet; and it's to save the reputation of her compatriots that the fairest and brightest of American girls should sacrifice a little of her independence.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Look here, Mr. Winterbourne, you make too much fuss: that's what's the matter with you!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: If I make enough to persuade you to go home with Mrs. Walker, my highest ambition will be gratified.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I think you are trying to mystify me: I can tell that by your language. One would never think you were the same person who went with me to that castle.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I am not quite the same, but I have a good deal in common with him. Now, Mr. Giovanelli doesn't resemble that person at all.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I don't know why you speak to me about Mr. Giovanelli.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Because — because Mrs. Walker asked me to.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: It would be better if she should do if herself.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: That's exactly what I told her; but she had an odd fancy that I have a kind of influence with you.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Poor Mrs. Walker!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Poor Mrs. Walker! She doesn't know that no one has any influence with you — that you do nothing in the world but what pleases yourself.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Whom, then, am I to please? The people that think such dreadful things of me? I don't even understand what they think! What do you mean, about my reputation? I haven't got any reputation! If people are so cruel and wicked, I am sure I would rather not know it. In America they let me alone, and no one ran after me, like Mrs. Walker. It's natural I should like the people who seem to like me, and who will take the trouble to go round with me. The others may say what they like. I can't understand Italian, and I should never hear of it if you didn't come and translate.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It's not only the Italians — it's the Americans.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Do you mean your aunt and your cousin? I don't know why I should make myself miserable for them!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I mean everyone who has ever had the very questionable advantage of making your acquaintance — only to be subjected to the torment of being unable either to believe in you or to doubt of you.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: To doubt of me? You are very strange!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: You are stranger still. But I didn't come here to reason with you: that would be vain, for we speak a different language, and we shouldn't understand each other. I only came to say to you, in the most respectful manner, that if you should consult your best interests you would go home with Mrs. Walker.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Do you think I had such a lovely time there, half an hour ago, when you didn't so much as look at me?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: If I had spoken to you, would you have stayed?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
After I had an engagement here?
( With a little laugh .)
I must say, you expect a great deal!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: What they say is true — you are a thorough-going coquette!

div.stage: (MRS. WALKER reappears, with GIOVANELLI.)

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You speak too much of what they say. To escape from you, I'll go anywhere!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.stage: ( To WINTERBOURNE, while GIOVANELLI speaks to DAISY.)
sp.p: He's very accommodating, when you tell him that if Mrs. Miller gets frightened she will start off for America.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: It's more than I can say of Miss Daisy!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: Have you had no success?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I have had my ears boxed!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: My precious child, you escaped from my drawing-room before I had half the talk we wanted.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Are they all waiting there to see me brought back?

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: Oh dear, no; they have plenty to think about — with Mrs. Costello and Miss Durant.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Ah, those ladies are there? Then I certainly shan't go back.

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: Hush! They're relations of Mr. Winterbourne.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: All the more reason for my hating them!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p:
You must excuse her; she is very wicked to-day!
( To DAISY.)
If you won't go home, then I'll stay with you here. Mr. Giovanelli, you promised me you would go to my house.

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p: I am at the orders of Mademoiselle.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You may do what you please till dinner-time.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Gracious heavens! is she going to dine with him?
( Aloud, to DAISY.)
We were interrupted, but I have a great deal more to say.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: More of the same sort? It will be a pleasure to hear that!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: What's coming is a great deal better. — Do you dine at your table d'hôte?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, yes. Randolph likes the table d'hôte.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I will ask for a place there this evening, and, with your permission, it shall be next to yours.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: I am very sorry, but I am not sure of this evening.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
That's a great disappointment to me.
( A short silence .)

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: You promised me you would go to my house!

sp.speaker: GIOVANELLI.
sp.p:
As a man of honor, then, I must go. But I assure you, Mademoiselle
( to DAISY)
that I soon return.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
As soon as you like!
(GIOVANELLI walks away. To WINTERBOURNE.)
Can't you come some other night?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Oh, yes, by waiting a little. But with the uncertainty of your stay in Rome, this would be always something gained.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: What will you do after dinner?

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: With your kind permission, I will adjourn with you to your mother's sitting-room.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You are very devoted, all of a sudden!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Better late than never!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: You are just as you were at that castle!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: So are you — at this moment. We can dream we are in that happy place!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p:
He can do with me what he will.
( Aloud, quickly .)
I'll tell them to keep you a seat!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: I shall be indebted to you forever!

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Oh, if I don't see about it, they'll put you at the other end.

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: Next you — that's the point.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Between me and Randolph! At half past six!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p: At half past six.

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: You can go about your business. I have something to say to her alone.

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: Don't forget half past six!

sp.speaker: WINTERBOURNE.
sp.p:
Never in the world. At half past six!
( Walks away .)

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p: And now may I be permitted to inquire whether you had arranged to dine with that Italian?

sp.speaker: DAISY.
sp.p: In the heart of ancient Rome! But don't tell Mr. Winterbourne what I gave up!

sp.speaker: MRS. WALKER.
sp.p:
I'll get you out of Rome to-morrow!
( Aloud .)
I must show you to the crowd — with me .
( Goes out leading DAISY.)

div.stage: (REVERDY, RANDOLPH.)

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.stage: ( Coming in just as the others pass out, and completing MRS. WALKER'S phrase .)
sp.p:
The wife of the American consul! The American consul is all very well, but I'll be hanged if I'll carry on the business! It's quite enough to do odd jobs for Mrs. Costello, without taking service at the consulate. Fifty carriages before the door, and five hundred people up-stairs. My companions may get up if they can! It's the first time to-day I've had a moment for a quiet smoke.
( Lights a cigar, and while he is doing so RANDOLPH comes in .)
O Lord, the Old Man of the Sea!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I say, Mr. Reverdy, suppose you offer me a cigar.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: My poor child, my cigars are as big as yourself!

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: There's nothing fit to smoke over here. You can't get 'em as you can in America.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I don't care what I pay. I've got all the money I want.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: Don't spend it; keep it till you grow up.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: Oh, I ain't going to grow up. I've been this way for ever so long. Mother brought me over to see if I wouldn't start, but I haven't started an inch. You can't start in this old country.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: The Romans were rather tall.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
sp.p: I don't care for the Romans. A child's as good as a man.

sp.speaker: REVERDY.
sp.p: The future of democracy! You remind me of the infant Hannibal.

sp.speaker: RANDOLPH.
